title: Unlocking Axon 7 from another Google account

thread.text: I came across a nearly new Axon 7 but the owner says it got locked to a friend's Google account by mistake and he's selling it as a result. Shouldn't doing a factory reset fix this and if not, how is it done? Thanks

No -- you need to know that person's Google account name and password. It's Factory Reset Protection, which is intended to discourage thieves from stealing a phone and doing a simple factory reset to make it their own.

title: Why can't I find any information about the axon 7s?

thread.text: I bought the axon 7s online from China and cannot find a manual. My keyboard has become sensitive and it types double letter, won't pick up LTE, and other issues. Anyone know anything about this phone?

My friend just got this phone and it seems to be Draining battery pretty fast. What's the average battery life you guys are getting out of he mini? I have the regular axon and I think it does ok but I know the mini has a smaller battery and lower speed processor. Is there anything that can be done to help the battery life last a bit longer?
We've cut off sync, went through power manager to limit some apps. Any suggestions?

It'd help to see some battery stats from your friend, since his use won't be exactly the same as yours. For example, he might be in an area of worse cell signal, which can kill battery.
Charge up to 100%, then let it drain to 20-30% with normal usage, without charging in between. Then show us:
1. The main Settings>Battery screen.
2. The fullscreen battery graph screen (which shows Awake time and Cell Signal Strength).
3. The Screen category (to see total Screen On time).
4. The Cell Standby category, if present (to see Time Without Signal).
You might have to install a 3rd party battery monitor, like GSam Battery Monitor, to get the Cell Signal Strength graph.

replies.text: This was one older screenshot from before I adjusted a few settings in power manager on the phone

thread.text: Can you show more of the screenshots I had recommended? It helps to see more information. The main thing I can see right now is that there's a lot of yellow in the cell signal strength, which is mediocre -- that can increase battery usage. There's also a lot of Awake time, so that might indicate some app that's inappropriately keeping the phone awake (although this can be hard to pinpoint).

It's definitely helpful to install Juice Defender which you can customize the settings from balanced to aggressive. I've used it for years with my Galaxy S3 and it works pretty well. title: Why Are Calls Coming Through When I'm On Do Not Disturb?

thread.text: Not sure if I'm missing a setting or something but I have the axon 7, and if I set it on do no disturb I have phone calls coming through. Is there a way to stop all calls and notifications from coming through when it's on do not disturb? Am I missing a setting? I'm on 7.1.1

Yes, there is Do Not Disturb mode you can configure. It has three options:
1. Priority
2. Alarm Only
3. Total silence.
Depending on the setting you chose, that Foxbat121 shows, you will still have calls go through. Change it to priority and you can manually choose what notifications you want or don't want.

hi guys, on Windows Mobile and iPhone, turning on Do Not Disturb basically rejects/disconnects calls from coming through ..the person calling doesnt actually get through at all and wont even hear a calling tone if they are not on a favorite/breakthrough list.. it simply disconnects them.

title: Sleeper phone of 2017, must read article!!

thread.text: Respond to this post of you own a Axon 7 Mini if you will. I'm curious as to how many of you owners are out there. If you have one then it's 100 percent safe to say you indeed have the sleeper phone of the year 2017. Think about it when you pick your phone up next time. Check out the build quality. The high end all metal no plastic premium build. Then go to YouTube and take a listen to your favorite song or watch your favorite movie or something. The speakers are nothing short of amazing. Then go to your browser and check out the speed of the 617 processor in this phone. It's plenty fast and zippy. In fact I've not experienced any lag in my Axon 7 Mini at all. Then open your camera up and take a few photos. They are crisp. They are clear. The shutter is fast. It's 16 megapixels strong. Then take a look at the amoled display. Check out how punchy the and vibrant the colors are. The resolution is sharp, crisp and clear even though it being 1080p it's HAD Amoled. Have I left anything out on this phone. If I have please feel free to add to my post more features about this phone as I want to see what I've left out that is important in what makes a phone good and not average. So with that said we us owners of this phone the Axon 7 Mini get all of the above mentioned for only $199. Taking all of that into account there is no other phone on the market that comes close to what you get with a Axon 7 Mini for the money you spend. I mean what other phone on the current market gives you top notch features some being flagship level such as the build and speakers that you can easily compare price wise to the Axon 7 Mini? I buy and sell a ton of phones. I mean a lot. I know for a fact that why this phone has not simply flown off the shelves is merely the fact that it's actually priced so low that most mobile phone consumers have written this phone off to be cheap and on par with that of of other sub 200 dollar phones which if you think about it, if you have not picked up this phone and held it, listened to it, browsed through web with it and take pictures with it you'd automatically think that you get what you pay for. So in fact this phone has been widely written off by even the major phone article companies to be that of a cheap $199 phone. Well they are right about it being cheap but they have omitted the most important thing. User quality. There is simply not another phone for this price that gives you anything near what the Axon 7 Mini gives you. I mean it's become my daily driver. For me to say that means something because I do go through just that many phones. Will it become my back up phone to my newest phone I have coming? Well yes, but that phone will have a 820 processor and was once a $700 dollar phone upon it's initial release meaning it was a flagship phone in 2016. What I'm saying is that there is a reason all of us Axon 7 Mini owners still have this phone and still use it on it on a daily basis. You get an upper level mid ranger device for the price of a very low tiered phone in today's current market standards. Look at the regular Axon 7 for example. That phone is flagship in every since of the word but you only pay $399 for it. That's the price of a decent mid ranger in itself right there. My conclusion is that most consumers and even professional writers which by the way I can do much better than most of them have simply written the Axon 7 Mini off to being portayed to that of in which the price would lead one to believe it is. Which is cheap. That can be the only reason this phone never took off. In fact it's the only reason. You know most people think they can put a price on everything meaning if you spend cheaply then you in turn buy cheaply meaning you get a cheap product. I'll be honest. This phone would have sold better had ZTE left the price at $299 because right then and there people automatically would have placed this phone in another category being a step up above cheap. To the professional writers, what's wrong in today's market that a company can produce quality and the consumer actually get a good deal as opposed to the price being the very means to a product being worthy or not. Simply put Axon 7 Mini owners out there we got what you call a good deal. What a nice breath of fresh air in such a greed filled industry we are in. My hats off to ZTE for going against the grain and offering a high level quality product at a below market value price which equals nothing more than a what is called a good deal. So in ending this post the Axon 7 Mini is by far and away the sleeper phone of 2017. To those consumers and writers who stuck their nose up to the $199 price tag, well shame on you for not doing the least bit of homework and research when only to look at a phones worth by it's price tag. This is the society we live in today. Writers included. Just because a phone is selling for $199 does not always mean it's made of cheap plastic and poor quality build. Sadly though majority of consumers and professional writers have simply done that here and wow did they get it entirely all wrong. This is the best and well made phone that $199 can buy and to those those that think just because it's $199 it's worthless, there is not a piece of plastic on this phone. The speakers are the best you can get in the idustfy. The processor is that of a mid range phone which that's what the Axon 7 Mini is. The 1080p amoked display cones both on mid range and flagship phones. There is just not any other way around the fact that majority of the market got it totally wrong on this phone. Pick this phone up and use it for a few weeks and then read my article again and tell me that price is everything and the quality of a product basically means nothing. I think by far and away this is the best mid range phone on the market for this price and that my friends is a absolute fact. Thank you for reading. Respond if I've missed anything or if you'd like to add anything here. I'm sure I've missed some things so definitely feel free to add your comments and thoughts to this post

I already made a comparison in post 2 .I am not saying that it isn't. I am just saying that because they use  does not give them a pass as a premium build.
Look at the Essential Phone. Technically, that is more premium than the Axon.

I already made a comparison in post 2 .I am not saying that it isn't. I am just saying that because they use  does not give them a pass as a premium build.
Look at the Essential Phone. Technically, that is more premium than the Axon.
This is fact. Build quality and build materials are definitely different things.
The engine comparison I made in post 2 screams that. I still will take a steel engine from Audi over a titanium one from Isuzu.
That's not build quality, the analogy you used is more akin to the function of the engine or phone and not the structural soundness. Use a better analogy to avoid confusion.

His analogy was fine. 
Titanium is a more premium material than steel, but Audi has far better build quality (they make superior engines than Isuzu).

Build quality is not design. Quality of materials, type of metal, forging process, impurities in the metal are all build quality. How the engine performs and the durability of a design over time isn't build quality. Again, that's the confusion. I think the build quality is fantastic and the software is a bit flawed.

You are incorrect. Build quality is literally fit and finish. You can use the best materials on the planet, but if you have rough edges, or things don't line up, etc your build quality is bad. "Quality of materials" is.....quality of materials. The material itself has no impact on how well you use that material.
Build quality is also longevity. The engine example is a perfect analogy for this. If you build an engine out of a fantastic material, but the precision of the machining isn't as good, or an improper amount of fuel is injected, your build quality is not good. Building with a lesser material, but with tighter tolerances and more precision....will equate to better longevity, and overall function, of the engine.
You are correct. Other person is incorrect.

title: Axon 7 Mini a good deal at $200?

thread.text:
It has everything I want in a budget phone:
AMOLED screen
USB-C
NFC for Android Pay
Stereo speakers
The only thing making me hesitate is the ugly black border around the screen and reports of bad battery life (though it should be better than my dinky iPhone SE).

replies.text:
Hello,
I've owned the iPhone SE twice and now I own the axon 7 mini. I can tell you from experience that the axon 7 mini has a bit better battery life than the SE. Also I've often asked the question, why isn't the axon 7 mini flying off the shelf!!!! At what you get for $199 is simply amazing. I've come to the conclusion that most people just write off the phone to be cheap and worthless seriously due to how low the price is thinking they aren't going to be getting much from the phone which is the total by far opposite. Premium build. Amazing front facing Dolby Atmos surround sound speakers. Heck those two alone right there are worth $199. It's the 2017 sleeper phone by far and away. Buy it with confidence my friend. I love mine. I got my Platinum Silver from Amazon for actually $194. I initially purchased the gold from Best buy thinking I'd be okay with it but I couldn't stand the gold color so I will say definitely get the color you like the best on the front end. Don't do like me and try and settle bc you don't want to wait lol. What color are you getting?

I, too, had the mini. It certainly is a great device, especially for the money. The only reason I sold it was to get the bigger screen and faster processor in the axon7. But, truthfully, the mini was almost just as fast. My axon7 3.5mm jack **** the bed. So I bought the new LG V30. OMG, If you thought the A7 sounded great through headphones, and it does, you've got to hear that ESS Sabre quad dac in the V30. It really is nothing short of incredible.

Oh and don't let that black boarder bother you at all. It's very small and I don't even notice mine at all actually. You can take that off your list along with the doubts of the battery. Now the battery isn't the best out there by any means but it's better than the SE is. It's got great stand by time too. If you aren't using it then you aren't using battery.

title: Is the Axon 7 still worth buying today?

thread.text: I own the Axon 7 Mini and I've been wanting the regular Axon 7 too but I wanted to find out if it's still a good buy today say like if I waited until a black Friday sale or something. I've always wanted one but I hear mixed reviews on it. So what should I do? Get one or pass on it?
ive had mine for about a year and still love it.

replies.text: That's good to hear. I've got it narrowed down to the honor 8 and axon 7. Now I need to decide which to get. Right now I just bought a 32g honor 8 which I'm sending back for a 64g or an axon 7.

thread.text: I hope you saw they plan to come out with the Axon 8.

replies.text: Where did you see that about the Axon 8? I've yet to hear or see anything about the Axon 8. Did it say if it will still have the same awesome speakers. This is a huge selling point to me of the Axon 7 from getting to see just how good they are with the Axon 7 mini model. Also I like all metal phones. I really hope they don't do two things which I'm afraid they will at least do one. One is making the screen into a 18.9 ratio. To me it makes absolutely zero sense to take away from the classic width of a screen and then make the phone taller which just takes away from the overall viewing experience as the phone becomes way too narrow. This is a major reason I got rid of my Samsung S8. The crazy not needed fad of the 18.9 ratio. Let's hope they won't join the fad but I'm betting they do just like every other company has so far. Number two getting away from the all high end premium metal body and build and going with the fragile glass front and back. ZTE makes an awesome built phone and that's bc it's all metal. Even the Axon 7 mini is identical to the Axon 7 in terms of high end build and the high end speakers. As long as they avoid these two major things then I'd be more happy to wait on the Axon 8 but I have to think one of these two major changes will be made for the Axon 8. I can deal with a glass build but I refuse the 18.9 crazy no sense making fad of just a way too narrow phone. It's absolutely horrible for movies and media. So if the Axon 8 is 18.9 then I won't even think of getting it and I'll opt for the Axon 7 even though it will be dated. I've wanted the phone since release but I never did get one for one reason or another. I personally want the silver model. The only downfall to the Axon 7 is the non back lit nav keys. I have to think that must have a learning curve in the dark being that they are so close together. Also it seems it's kind of hard to still buy a new Axon 7 anymore as they are mostly sold out everywhere. So I'm unsure if I'll ever have a chance to get one as I just bought the 64g pearl white honor 8 which is my all time favorite phone. I'm a huge fan and supporter of EMUI software. It's vastly different than Android the highly unique so I bought it to become my now long term daily driver. The Axon 7 if I get one will not be my daily phone bc of the large 5.5 size. I prefer a smaller one handed device for my daily driver and the honor 8 is almost perfect for that. If it were 5.1 it would in fact be perfect. I can use the 5.2 inch size with one hand but it's a bit of a stretch in some cases. The Axon 7 would be my media phone for movies and web browsing. Plus I like the quad hd display too. I may just buy one used instead of new to save money if I can find a silver. I can't do the gold as I am not a fan at all. I just know the Axon 7 mini is the sleeper phone of 2017 so I have to think the Axon 7 is a heck of a phone for the money. It's a flagship in every step of the way to me.

thread.text: Still a good phone I'd recommend even with the axon 8 coming
ZTE's own Twitter account confirmed it but didn't give any more information.
https://www.androidauthority.com/zte...cessor-811801/

That's awesome. Now I have to wonder if they will use that dreaded 18.9 inch ratio. I so hope they don't. Like I said I've been wanting the Axon 7 for some time now but now I'm going to wait until they make their announcement along with the specs and type build of the phone. I think they should stick to what the Axon 7 offered but amp up the specs and tweak it here and there. I think the Axon 7 is an amazing device for the money. It's definitely a flagship but without the flagship way over priced pricing.
But they could follow the crowd and start charging more. Gawd I hope not.
I was going to pull the trigger on it last year. I think I'd still buy it today or at least consider it; however I'm waiting to see if they will make a successor to the Axon 7!

thread.text: So I've decided to return my Honor 8 to B&H and try and locate a like new used Axon 7. I've seen all kinds of prices on swappa, eBay and Amazon. Ideally I'd like to spend around $200 to $225. Is this a current market value on a used Axon 7 or should I expect to pay more than that for one used. Any insight or advice would be greatly appreciated.
I would expect more. I got them when they were on sale, but now they seem to be like finding a kid trying to find that rare baseball card. 250 and up at swappa I would expect.

I was using my Axon 7 recently when I saw I couldn't save any photos. I thought this was odd so I restarted my phone and then found that every single one of my photos was now GONE and I STILL could't save anymore. I then reset the cache. Still nothing. I then went into my file sorter app and saw that while all of my photos were still in their correct locations, there wasn't any folders to hold them. That's right, it shows that all of my photos were indeed in their correct folders, BUT the folder count was 0. I have no idea how this even happens but I would like to be able to see my photos from my camera roll again and not through a third party app that I have to screenshot every time. I'm just presuming downloaded photos aren't saving because the file destination isn't correct.

Use your file manager app to find the DCIM folder in the phone. Then look in there, and in the folders that are in there.
(If they're really gone, and you never backed them up, you'll have learned a lesson - always back up any important files on any computer. The old computer line is, "any file you haven't backed up is a file you don't need".)

Works fine for me
The only problem I had was having it try to finish the upgrade. If if won't upgrade make sure to take the SD card out first.

thread.text:
i don't know what fi is, but I've been using mine with Verizon for a few weeks now. it was a little bit of a pain because my previous phone uses a Micro-SIM card, and the Axon7 uses a Nano-SIM. i called verizon and told them i bought a new phone and needed a nano-SIM. they asked what phone i was getting and i told them Axon7 and the gal on the phone kept telling me it's not found in their "approved phone" list. i basically had to get firm with her and let her know that i've done the research and the phone takes a nano-SIM and to please send me one. 
i got it in the mail 2 days later. i popped it in and it didn't work. i then had to call verizon and told them i got a new SIM and needed it activated in my new phone. i had to read her the serial # on the side of the box that the SIM card came in, and the agent on the phone activated it and then it worked. i do have to keep it "roaming", but there is no roaming charges unless i leave the country, so it's been no problem. getting messages and phone calls just fine. also using LTE with no probs. the only downside i've heard of is that you can't access internet while using the phone, but i've never had to do that, so no prob for me. also heard wifi calling doesnt work either, but never used that either, so no prob for me.

title: Axon 7 Text Sounds Won't Change Separately From Notification Sounds

thread.text:
I'm trying to set my text tone different from the general notification sound but when I change its still playing the general notification sound
Anyone else having this issue?
My text are still coming through with the glow tone instead of the custom tone I have set

If someone starts a new SMS conversation with you, does it give you the correct tone?
Open your Messaging app, select one of your conversations, tap Menu>People & Options>Notifications -- does your preferred tone show up there? I'm not entirely sure of the sequence, but after I upgraded from a Nexus 6P to a Pixel XL, the older messages that got copied over were assigned the system's default notification tone, even though I set the notification tone for the Messaging app to something else. So with older message threads, I have to manually change the custom tone for that thread to the one I want. New message threads, however, have the proper custom tone. Hope that makes sense.

replies.text: Ended up figuring it out. My textra app still had the default sound set even though I changed it in settings I had to go into the textra app and change the sound there in order for it to change

title: Why has my axon 7 mini not received the 7.1.1 update yet?

thread.text: So I just got the axon 7 mini today. It's supposed to be running 7.1.1 but I'm still on 6.0.1 for some reason and have not received the automatic updates for this. So I downloaded the two updates and I need help with actually getting them to manually install now. Does someone mind stepping me through the process to manually push these two updates? Also why have I not received these two updates automatically since they've already been released? The main reason I bought this phone was bc it said it was running nougat 7.1.1 but I'm still stuck on 6.0.1. Please help. Thanks very much.

Does anyone know why my new axon 7 mini has not received my nougat update yet? I called ZTE and absolutely got nowhere with them. Shouldn't have the updates been waiting to be downloaded when I turned on the device? I only had one automatic update but I'm still running 6.0.1. Will I eventually receive the updates. I've found links to the two updates which I downloaded but I can't figure out how to manually install them from the download. Can anyone give me some help or let me know if I just need to wait on the automatic updates? I would have thought these updates would have been ready to download at boot up. ZTE was no help to me so I need some advice if you guys don't mind. One of the reasons I bought this device was bc it said it was running the latest software. Please help. Thanks very much
Does anyone know how to help me manually install the update? I've downloaded the file but I'm not sure how to get to install from there.

1. Installing downloaded updates by yourself voids your warranty. (And there are a lot of "updates" out there that are viruses.)
2. Even assuming that Axon has rewritten 7.11 for your model phone, they send it out in small batches to keep from overloading the server. Try Settings/About device/Software update. (If you try it more than once in 24 hours, you'll be told that you have the current update - again, to prevent overloading the servers.)
3. If what you downloaded is a legitimate update supplied by Axon, there should be instructions either in the download or, more likely, on the web page you downloaded the update from.

replies.text: I can see an OEM threatening that, but if they offer it on their own site, isn't that threat nullified?
I don't think it's legal nullification, but I can see them hosting the files "just for repair shops" or some such thing. I doubt that HTC still allows rooting.

thread.text: If yours is a US version, zteusa.com has the update files that you can download and update manually. The instructions are also posted there. IIRC, you need a microSD card to install it.

How do I move them to the SD card and will I need to boot in some type of recovery mode to manually push the updates? I've never done it before so I'm going in blind. Any help step by step would be greatly appreciated man. I've tried to research it and I'm getting all kinds of different instructions. I downloaded one file but I could not find a way to move it to the SD card though so I erased it and started over. My first update is about complete. Will I need to boot in a different mode to manually push the update or will the system auto update detect it and take the update? I'm hoping this nougat update will help the small battery on the Axon I have as it doesn't last very long. It's got quick charge and usb c type port so those are pluses too. If I don't get the Moto Z Play then it'll be another Honor 8 as I used that phone for a good while or probably the longest since I switched over to Android a little over a year ago now from Apple. Anyways overall this Axon 7 mini is a steal for under 200 so I couldn't pass it up. Plus I think the quality of the build far exceeds it's price point.

thread.text: Each carrier has its own limit on the maximum size of the allowed picture or video inside a MMS. Ideally, the software will know the limits and automatically compress them before sending. But given that this is an unlocked phone not tied to any carrier, you just have to do it yourself.

title: Thinking about getting a Axon 7, or should I wait now?

thread.text:
Hello to all,
I've watched several reviews on the Axon 7 and now I'm thinking about getting one. My question is, should I now wait since the Axon 8 isn't too far from being released? I want to make the right decision and wanted to get some major feedback as to what I should do. The 7 seems like a awesome device but if the 8 is not too far off, would I be making a mistake not waiting now? Any help or suggestions would be greatly appreciated! Does anyone know or heard when the 8 will be released? The 7 appears to be a heck of a device but I don't want to waste money if the 7 is about to go on sale pretty soon. I'm not sure what I should do. Help!!

Oh and I forgot to ask. How's the battery life on the 7? If you are fully charged on average how long throughout the day can you go before you need to get it on a charger. Currently I have the BlackBerry PRIV and it seems to eat through battery life pretty quickly. Luckily it doesn't take long to recharge it but if I'm going to be somewhere all day I don't want to have to worry my phone will die. Does the 7 get you guys through an entire day no problem?

I would get it now you can always sell it 200 or so towards the new phone. I don't think the new phone will be that big of a difference from this one actually. It's a great phone I just bought it at the beginning of the month. Battery life is great with heavy usage I can squeeze about 7 - 8 hours with light or medium usage can get roughly 12 or so hours.
There's battery saving options like the ultra battery saver mode that can push it to last even longer
I'm a heavy Fb and instagram user and Fb is a bigbattery drain so if u don't use Fb u can expect longer battery life
Also the phone has quick charge 3.0 so even if u get low on battery it recharges fast roughly 60% in 30 mins

replies.text:
Thanks man. I'm highly considering picking one up. It seems like it's a top notch device all the way around. Do you by chance know when the 8 is supposed to be released? Just wondering because as soon as it does the 7 will go on sale and I don't want to spend $400 and then a month later it drop to $299 on me. I don't have to have the 8 either. The 7 is plenty of phone but I don't want to sell myself short if I can save $100 dollars that is if the 8 is about to be released. Anyone heard or know?
Sent from my STV100-1 using AC Forums mobile app
If I'm not mistaken the 7 was released last July so I would look for news of a new phone around July or August
I may hold off then and wait and check out the Axon 8 or then buy the Axon 7 on sale. Once the 8 hits the 7 will drop. Thanks for the heads up on that.

replies.text: From what I've seen of the 7 they are really going to have to do something special as the 7 appears to be one heck of a device. I know it will have the 835 processor so that's a plus already. I still may yet get the 7 but I'm not sure yet. I want to see more about the 8 first.

thread.text: Im still very tempted to get the 7 even though the 8 is around the corner. Amazon has the color I want for 369 dollars. That's a pretty good price.

I have the A7 and just got the new OnePlus 5. I can tell you that the A7 is far from being outdated. It's still very much competitive compared to all the new phones coming out now. And sometimes superior. The display and the sound of the A7 is still the best out there. The stereo speakers are impressive, really. Changes the way you listen to songs when you use them, and it's the same with movies. The O+5 has only one speaker, and... well it's nice but nothing compared to the A7. The QHD display is fantastic too. 
The processor is still blazingly fast, some lags here and there but I guess it's because of the applications, not the phone. 
The rest of the hardware is also still competitive. 4GB RAM is enough and the storage + microSD adequate. 
The only downside I think is the community around the A7. It's there, but it's way less than the one of OnePlus. When you have a problem, it takes longer to find a way to fix it, when you can. The updates are a bit of a hassle to get and to install. You have to know what you're doing. And you're not alway up to date... Security wise, I think my A7 is not at its best. 
The OS is "almost" Android Stock, so it's good. 
So yes, you can get an A7, it's still one of my favorite phone around. I'm keeping it aside the O+5 so I can make a clear choice. But it's going to be a hard one...

replies.text: Very well written. I appreciate that and your time. The one plus 5 is an impressive device too. It's not cheap either. If you place the Axon 7 up there with it then I'll most likely get one. I was going to wait for the Axon 8 but after your very well written post I think I will go ahead and opt for the 7 now. We'll done and thank you for your time and response.

thread.text: I took my project fi sim out of my A7, popped in my Verizon sim, followed instructions on the web for setting up the device including new APN settings. I was able to make and receive calls without issue. But texts were another problem. I used both Textra and the stock texting app and got the same results. I put in a number and texted "hi" . To my surprise, I received a text back from a number that wasn't even remotely close to the number I put in. I just said wrong number. This happened a few times so I gave up. What would cause this to happen?
Have you deleted your old settings?

If you're referring to the old Apn settings, no because you just enter the new settings under a new heading for verizon. When your verizon sim is in, you simply click on the Verizon setting. When you have your fi sim in, you click on T-mobile.

I haven't been involved with Project Fi, but I've wondered if it is similar to Google Voice. When I dial a number in Google Voice, it shows on the screen as I enter the numbers correctly but when I press send, it shows a random number in the box that says Dialing XXX-XXX-XXXX. Something completely different than what I dialed. I haven't done any text messages but I would imagine it does the same thing. The curious thing is that no matter what number it says it is dialing, the person who answers is at the number that I entered in at the beginning.

replies.text: Right, but I've got my Verizon sim card in the A7. Not the fi sim so that shouldn't be happening.

thread.text: Verizon still primarily use CDMA radio for calls and text. The CDMA part only works if the device is certified by Verizon. So, you are basically only using LTE radio. Verizon does support some fashion of VoLTE and SMS over LTE but does not work reliably without using their Messaging app.
Have you tried adding the 1 before the area code?

I'm getting roughly 7 hours out of my phone with medium to heavy use. I'm new to Android in general so I was wondering are there any battery saving tips in general? 
I notice there's ALOT of power management tools on this phone I guess included by ZTE.
How do I disable apps from running in the background? Any tips or advice for maximizing the battery on the Axon 7

With the 7.1.1 update, you can tweak each app with regarding on how to save battery. Go to Settings app->Power Manager->power management for apps. 
Be careful installing apps. Some apps are awfully designed and will waste a lot of battery. I only install minimal amount of apps that I need. And have no problem for the phone last more than one day.
Is that screen on time? If so, it is pretty good.

I've only had it 2 days. So why a review so soon? Read on. Let me say first off that I'm a tech junkie. I've had 8 smartphones in less than a year. The ones I like, I keep. I sell the rest. So, I'm comparing the A7 to the LG v10, galaxy note 4, S6 edge, S7 edge, nexus 5x, nexus 6p, Google pixel, and axon 7 mini. I bought the A7 because of its superior audio system. I was so impressed with the mini, that i decided on going full tilt. Upon opening the box, you could see right away the quality built into this phone. Every inch of the A7 was a perfect fit. Using the "we share" app transferring all apps and files from the mini, was an effortless task. Not only were these transfered to my new device, but they were also set up 100% correctly as they were in the mini. So after updating 22 apps and doing a system update, I was ready to rock & roll with the new axon in less than 40 minutes. Im using project fi in this phone so I'll be on the T-mobile network. I also slipped an already loaded 128gb sd card into it so my media, both music and HD movies, were good to go. So far there have been no hiccups of any kind. The A7 is fast, smooth, and does everything you ask it to without a hitch. Calls were very clear. And the screen very vivid and colorful. It was nice to receive such a high end product WITHOUT getting ripped off. The audio system on this phone, complete with dolby atmos, is outatanding through speakers and headphones. And, yes, better than the v10. I'm so happy with the A7 that it will become my main phone. I have an S7 edge that I also love, but the audio on it is very much lacking. The screen is a bit better than the A7 though. Now as far as the new pixel is concerned, Google can keep it. The battery life is outstanding, but excellent on my A7 and S7, but, really, nothing else is great on it. Its the worst 700.00 bucks I ever spent. It's also ugly as sin. So I hope you all enjoy your ZTE axon 7 phones as much as I am. If you have any questions, lets talk about it.

Had bought my son a 6p....it got up to a whopping 170 degrees per gsam and the phone itself and kept shutting down. Was using it's included charger. Moved to the Axon 7 after the Honor 8 was eh and it is a very very nice phone. You get so much for what you pay for. I think I payed 520.00 total after a price adjustment.
Best buy has it for 350.00 plus a 50.00 gift card. (I always get protection because ya know, kids). BH Photo same price but with free headphones.
For 350.00 plus a $50.00 gift card IMHO you can't go wrong. Buttons take some getting used to, and the fingerprint sensor is good but not great. But it is a solid phone. The packaging, the device itself, etc. is fantastic. Worth every penny.
How is the camera on the Axon 7 ?

replies.text: I found that outdoor shots and indoor under. Good lighting, come out very well. In low light conditiobs, you may be a little disappointed.

In all honesty, what camera in a phone is going to give you amazing shots in low light conditions? No phone out today can compete with my DSLR...But I don't expect my phone to do that.
Sensors are sensors, and there isn't much difference between them overall.
You should use a galaxy S7 or S7 edge camera. While I'm sure it won't compete with a dslr, the indoor, low light shots are spectacular.
The Axon 7 does fine for me. The only light in the room is from my monitor.

By headphones I must say only over Super settings it is really good. Dolby with like the Audio-Technica ATH M50x sucks. 
I have the LG V10 also. Like by the Bayerdynamic DT 770 LE 32 Ohm the Axon have not enough power. Here is the LG V10 louder after you trigger the high gain mode. Both phones sound pretty equal with their special dac and amp. 
I have the global version of the Axon 7 with firmware B09.
The Axon 7 is way louder and still clear compared to my HTC 10 which is no slouch in that department. It's an amazing device.

thread.text: I picked up the Axon 7 during black Fri/Christmas sale at a very good price. I was using it as my main daily driver for almost two weeks and I decided to return the phone. Overall, the Axon 7 is really nice, signal was good, sq was good, worked with project fi. Built quality was really good. The only few problems I have with the phone is: The Axon 7 randomly reboot itself. it happened more than 5 times while I had the phone. the second issue is: I occasionally had to repair bluetooth devices, I don't really know why? All I know is the device was no longer paired and I just had to repair it. Those were the two issues I have during the two weeks. The BT repairing doesn't bother me much.. The reboot does. 2 out of the 5 reboots was while I am in the meeting; the other was just random reboot for no reason. I hope these issues don't happen to anyone else.

replies.text: Both of your issues can be solved with Textra. I have been using it for a while and you can reply from the pull down and customize emojis. There are several Textra emoji packs available free in the play store.

thread.text: Well, emojis can be in the SMS app and the keyboard. I addressed the SMS because you mentioned that. I use SwiftKey as my keyboard as well. Not sure which emojis SwiftKey offers but it's free as well. This is the beauty of Android. It's all customizable.

For me, it had everything I wanted at a price that couldn't be ignored - $199 sale at Best Buy last December. It had all the other features I wanted; midrange, SD expansion, NFC, not too big screen, more than adequate battery life. Performance has never been an issue for me, but I am no power user. The most stressful thing I use it for is maps/nav while streaming podcasts over Bluetooth in the car. It does that just fine without any stuttering. My old original Moto G just couldn't handle that.

Ok, so far I love the phone other than one thing. The dialer app won't open. I tap on the dialer and it dims showing that I tapped it, but it won't open. I can make calls from my contact list but can't open the dialer. Any ideas?

Oh, and another one. There is a line of grey pixels running down the left side of the screen on the homescreens only. This is in the stock launcher and Nova, but doesn't appear in any apps pics or anything else. Just homescreen.
Ok, figured out the nova phone icon problem. Just had to delete the phone icon and re add it from the app drawer. Still, the weird grey pixel line though only on home screen.

thread.text: I have the ZTE Axon 7 (64 gb) with Nova Launcher, and my update went fine. After the reboot, the default launcher was switched to Stock Android, but I just reselected Nova Launcher as the default launcher and it was fine.

After it turns off and back on it comes up to a menu.
Android recovery
Reboot to Bootloader
Apply update from ADB
Apply update from SD card
Wipe data/factory reset
Wipe cache partition
View recovery logs
Run Graphics test
Power off.
You can try wiping the cache partition. If the update, still won't take, you may have to do a data reset.

Is your phone rooted or completely stock?

The only thing I can recommend at this point would be to do a factory data reset. I would not restore from a backup, but start fresh. As soon as you reset your phone, sign into your WiFi and the update should be available for OTA download and should install. Of course, the reset will wipe any pictures, music etc. you have stored on internal storage. If they're on an SD card, that's OK. Make sure your contacts are saved to your Google account so you can import them once you reset. Like I said, in my case it was the Nova Launcher that caused the update not to match. You may have installed some app that changed a system file. Anyway, unless someone else has a suggestion, a data reset is the only way I know that should work.

My wife's phone. She hands it to me today and says. " it's stuck...can you fix it"?
Apparently not. Get the black and white screen that says "You are in Factory Test Mode (FTM). Push power to turn off and then oush power again to start normally. It doesn't. I get right back to FTM and that is it.
I noticed that her volume rocker seems stuck somehow, such that it is stuck on Down or stuck on Up. If it's in the Swing position...I'm getting the FTM. If it's stuck in the Up position...I get nothing (although I SHOULD get recovery mode)
I have no idea what's going on here. Any help would be appreciated. Thanks.

It looks like Power and Vol Down boots into Factory Test Mode, as described here: https://forum.xda-developers.com/zte...tions-t3178894 So I suspect that the Vol Down button is stuck in a pressed state. Unless you're willing to open the phone up and mess with the volume button yourself, I suggest bringing it to a repair shop.

I just had this problem myself today. I was able to get out of Factory Test mode by following the instructions as written. But, it took me several tries because I guess I was impatient. You have to hold the power button down a *very* long time (as these things go). Much longer than I've had to do for any special Android mode, including entering bootloader, factory reset, whatever. I'd say it was at least 30 seconds, but I wasn't timing it. 
Also, not sure it's relevant, but it could be. After my first failures, I downloaded the Mobogenie PC software to connect to my phone that way. Again, it took quite a while for the software to recognize the connection, and then it reported a failure. Somewhere in there is when I just held down my power button for the *very* long time, and all of a sudden the screen went dark, then got the boot screen and all was well. 
Ya i get it, very loosey-goosey and stupid repair steps but that's what I got because I lucked into it, and I'm not gonna repeat it because I don't want to take any chances .
Hope this helps someone else though. Cheers.

thread.text:
Hey gang. I picked up an Axon 7 mini the other day at best but. I thought I'd share some quick thoughts on it. 
The build quality and size of it are awesome. For a price of only 300 it's amazing. I think the size is just right. The gold body of the phone looks really clean as well. The screen was very bright and vivid and colors looked great. 
The rear facing camera was decent and the front facing left a little to be desired. I don't take a lot of selfies though. 
Where the phone started to show its price point however was speed. I'm coming from the htc 10 and it cooks. It felt just a half second slow compared to that. I know the 10 costs about twice as much so if you didn't come from a more "premium" phone you probably wouldn't see an issue. But it was a fun little impulse purchase but unfortunately I decided to return it to best buy. Honestly though for 300 bucks it's pretty impressive. 
Just some quick thoughts. Thanks for reading.

I've only had it 2 days. So why a review so soon? Read on. Let me say first off that I'm a tech junkie. I've had 8 smartphones in less than a year. The ones I like, I keep. I sell the rest. So, I'm comparing the A7 to the LG v10, galaxy note 4, S6 edge, S7 edge, nexus 5x, nexus 6p, Google pixel, and axon 7 mini. I bought the A7 because of its superior audio system. I was so impressed with the mini, that i decided on going full tilt. Upon opening the box, you could see right away the quality built into this phone. Every inch of the A7 was a perfect fit. Using the "we share" app transferring all apps and files from the mini, was an effortless task. Not only were these transfered to my new device, but they were also set up 100% correctly as they were in the mini. So after updating 22 apps and doing a system update, I was ready to rock & roll with the new axon in less than 40 minutes. Im using project fi in this phone so I'll be on the T-mobile network. I also slipped an already loaded 128gb sd card into it so my media, both music and HD movies, were good to go. So far there have been no hiccups of any kind. The A7 is fast, smooth, and does everything you ask it to without a hitch. Calls were very clear. And the screen very vivid and colorful. It was nice to receive such a high end product WITHOUT getting ripped off. The audio system on this phone, complete with dolby atmos, is outatanding through speakers and headphones. And, yes, better than the v10. I'm so happy with the A7 that it will become my main phone. I have an S7 edge that I also love, but the audio on it is very much lacking. The screen is a bit better than the A7 though. Now as far as the new pixel is concerned, Google can keep it. The battery life is outstanding, but excellent on my A7 and S7, but, really, nothing else is great on it. Its the worst 700.00 bucks I ever spent. It's also ugly as sin. So I hope you all enjoy your ZTE axon 7 phones as much as I am. If you have any questions, lets talk about it.

title: Which Nougat features have you found?

thread.text:
With the latest 7.0 on your A7 what goodies have you found?
Any clever shortcuts to the neat things going on in Nougat?
Display, Display size, use this and helps me see screen better with my low vision.

At first I thought notifications were broken until I realized they're bundled now.
Much, much better actually.
Also saving as RAW under manual in the camera app is nice.
At least I can dabble with pics I'd like to save in Lightroom.

I like the dual app feature where you can run two apps at the same time. Just long press the app switch button and your current app will move to the top half of the screen and you can choose a second app to fill the bottom half.
Not all apps are compatible with the dual app mode but most are. I like being able to watch a video using VLC on one side of the screen while having a recipe on the other side while I'm cooking something.
The new Bluetooth skipping feature is awesome, makes every song into techno!

i don't know what fi is, but I've been using mine with Verizon for a few weeks now. it was a little bit of a pain because my previous phone uses a Micro-SIM card, and the Axon7 uses a Nano-SIM. i called verizon and told them i bought a new phone and needed a nano-SIM. they asked what phone i was getting and i told them Axon7 and the gal on the phone kept telling me it's not found in their "approved phone" list. i basically had to get firm with her and let her know that i've done the research and the phone takes a nano-SIM and to please send me one. 
i got it in the mail 2 days later. i popped it in and it didn't work. i then had to call verizon and told them i got a new SIM and needed it activated in my new phone. i had to read her the serial # on the side of the box that the SIM card came in, and the agent on the phone activated it and then it worked. i do have to keep it "roaming", but there is no roaming charges unless i leave the country, so it's been no problem. getting messages and phone calls just fine. also using LTE with no probs. the only downside i've heard of is that you can't access internet while using the phone, but i've never had to do that, so no prob for me. also heard wifi calling doesnt work either, but never used that either, so no prob for me.

thread.text: It's awesome IMO. I can be charged back up mega fast if I dip below 50% and need a full phone (my old Zenfone 2 was fast as well, but still slower than the A7). One of fastest charging phones I've had. Love it.
I love the quick charge on my Axon 7...tops up really quick... Like 80% in 30 mins is awesome... Way faster than my s7 edge

I never charge my phone at night any more, even though I have a charger right there on my nightstand. My phone gets charged entirely on the 20 minute drive to work, and the reverse drive going home. I go all weekend without charging, and still come Monday have 50-ish battery life left on most weekend.
I've heard the Axon 7 has great quick charging. That was one thing that tempted me to purchase it.
It charges fast on the top end its impossible to go from 0 to 100 in about 90 minutes.

You can charge the A7 from 20% to 80% in about 30mins, and then it charges the battery with less speed, let's say a "normal" speed.
That's why I don't care about its autonomy anymore, QC3.0 is really great (y)

Update:
I charged my phone to 100% and unplugged it yesterday (Thurs Feb 2) at 7am. I used it on and off all day/night yesterday (emails, texts, Spotify,surfing) and went to bed with it at 52%. So I opted to not charge it last night and here I am Friday morning and I'm at 51% and will see how far I can go before I opt to charge it back up.

replies.text: That's great battery life...

thread.text: Well I tested this again and I'm literally almost at the same level as I was in the above scenario. It's 8am on day 2 and I'm at 51% to start the day.

Ok so now we are in the Nougat phase of things and as of 2:15pm today (unplugged from charger at usual time of 7am) I'm at 75% battery life. Mainly texting and bit of surfing today. 
So far am still happy with the battery life of this bad boy!

replies.text: Absolutely not. Let me start by saying that I own a samsung galaxy S7 edge, Google pixel, and the axon7. My favorite out of the 3-the axon7. The galaxy S7 EDGE would be number 1 if it had a great sound system, but it doesnt. Im an audiofile and listening to my music through my bose headphones is priority. The axon7 has the very best hifi dacs and dolby atmos to put you right in with the band. And watching movies is also an incredible experience. Music aside , the rest of this device can stand up with the best. It's fast, works flawlessly with zero hiccups in the month that ive had it. It beats pixel hands down and the only thing that the s7 edge has over it is the screen. Not that the axon7 screen is bad. Contrary, its bright, beautiful. But the s7 edge curve is unique. Forget about price, i think its the best smartphone right now.

Why do u have 3 phones? 
I would also say the s7 and pixel has better camera/video compared to axon 7.

First, as far as the camera, in low light yes. Outdoor pics almost just as good. I don't have 3 phones. I've got 4. I didn't mention the ZTE axon 7 mini. I was so impressed I bought the axon7 for the better screen, camera and speed. I started the year(2015) with th LG V10. It was a good phone, fast enough, but had to many lows. Only the 808soc, a good screen but nothing compared to the S6 edge I gave up. Bad battery life. But worst of all, it was a huge, uncomfortable to hold and carry beast. So after 4 months as soon as the S7 edge hit I grabbed one and sold the monster. I really love my S7 edge. Its the perfect size, extremely fast, always reliable, great battery life, that curved superamoled screen but poor audio system. Then I fell for Googles hype and bought what was supposed to be the elite of elite phones, the pixel. What a let down. Just an average phone not worth half what they were asking. So when the axon7 mini went on sale, I bought one and fell head over heals with its unbeatable audio system. So when the black friday deals came out, I upgraded to the regular Axon 7. Its been a joy. Beats pixel hands down and keeps right up with the S7 edge except the curved screen on S7 EDGE is a bit better. So now I'm back to carrying only 1 device, my axon7. And I'm loving it. I'll save the other 3 for when the axon 8 comes out. I'll sell the pixel, axon 7 mini, and S7 EDGE. And get the 8. I always keep another phone for a backup. You never know. If the galaxy S8 has a hifi dac system, I may consider that one, but only after I see what ZTE has in store for the axon 8.

The Axon 7 seems like it is a nice phone. However, I am leery about buying another ZTE phone after experiencing their abysmal support for the Axon Pro. When it came out, about a year before the Axon 7, it was billed as a reasonably priced flagship alternative with a similar price to the current Axon 7. The Axon Pro is not a bad phone, although the software experience isn't the smoothest. The problem is that after upgrading the phone to Marshmallow, ZTE has abandoned any software support including security updates. If this was a $100 phone I could forgive the lack of support. The Axon 7 will definitely be upgraded to Nougat. However, don't be surprised if the phone is abandoned by ZTE afterwards.

I can see this happening it's always a concern for a lot of us.
Not intensely worried however since I'm used to most of my other phones having been dropped as far as updates.
Huawei/Honor might end up the winner for phone updates which just might set a trend for other manufacturers.
I'll be good for a year with N and app updates then it will be on to another great midship phone for me.

replies.text: I hope you're right about this. OnePlus has also been more conscientious about putting out updates since the introduction of the OnePlus 3. Ironically it seems like recently the carrier based versions of phones from Motorola, Samsung, LG, etc. have had more consistent updates than the unlocked versions, like the MOTO Z and Samsung Galaxy. Things really haven't changed that much. The overwhelming majority of cell phone sales are still tied to carriers despite the supposed elimination of contracts.

thread.text: Just about all companies drop support after one year...or maybe 18 months. The manufacturer does not make money on providing software updates. They have to pay people to make the latest software work on "older" hardware without getting anything back...except possibly customer loyalty. The main way they make money is by getting people to buy a new phone. Business.

replies.text: ZTE dropped any support for the Axon Pro in less than 6 months I would have been happy if they supported the phone for 18 months. For their flagship devices most companies are promising updates for 2 years now. It is not good business for companies to drop support so quickly. Because of the way they treated customers that bought the Axon Pro a lot of people, including me, will not buy another phone from ZTE.

thread.text:
Well I guess I've looked at the A7 long enough.
Here are 10 thoughts about it:
Works fine on T-Mobile and an MVNO using the AT&T network.
LTE and Wi-Fi connections for me have been bulletproof so far.
No drops and no slowdowns in the Sacramento CA area.
Goes without saying music from this thing is stellar.
Amazing we can enjoy such sound clarity and detail from these devices.
Screen is gorgeous as far as I can see. 
I'm not overly nit-picky about screens tho.
Call quality is good.
I won't use this for calls much however even with VoLTE.
Had no trouble simply sliding a SIM in and having MMS work here.
Another great device I bought recently had a problem with MMS on AT&T.
Not the A7 though no problems sending MMS at all "yay!"
The ZTE MiFavor OS features are ok for me.
Close to stock so I'm not disappointed or overly excited either.
Impressed with the manufacturing quality of this phone.
Very good feel to it with some weight.
So happy I got the dark grey one.
Again very nice.
Fingerprint sensor is OK.
Fails about once in five tries.
I may need to reset the fingerprint profiles.
Good enough overall yet not the fastest.
Non-lit hardware navigation keys are driving me nutz.
I was worried about this so I'm using one of the after market onscreen key apps in order to alleviate frustration there.
A 3rd party app is workable so far since MiPop was somewhat irritating for this user.
I'm not using the default camera app.
Opted for "Snap Camera" instead:https://play.google.com/store/apps/d...naptrial&hl=en
The camera is pretty dismal in lower light of course.
I'll need to fiddle with it more to hopefully get better results there.
Good light pics look sharp and pleasing to me although somewhat bland without a little post processing.
I'm not displeased with the camera due to it's features and potential.
I was a bit surprised this phone doesn't show as camera 2 API capable.
At least it showed "failed" when checking.
Smartphone camera performance seems all over the board these days anyway.
Maybe the checker I used is unreliable?https://play.google.com/store/apps/d...ity_test&hl=en
I won't go on...these were things I wanted to touch on being a brand new user.
A new phone is always so much fun!

I really wonder what some poster are still doing on this forum. If you're so disappointed with the A7, why haven't you moved on to something else? Why are you still posting here? Still using something that you don't like? Sounds weird to me... not very... smart.
Hey guys excited at last my Axon 7 premium version has arrived 128gb with 6gb ram and force touch... Today 1st day with it... Getting use to it... So far lovin it

I seriously considered returning this Axon 7 because of the hardware keys. I didn't pick this phone up for a while. Actually started a return for it on Amazon then cancelled the following day.
After a cooling off period and finding the simple control app I'm a lot happier.
This really is a fine well made phone in my opinion. 
Benefits have won over any disappointment.
Anyhoo just a small update.
All is well...

title: First impressions of the Axon 7 switching from OnePlus 3

thread.text:
tl;dr: It compares very well vs the OnePlus 3. Axon has the advantage on screen and sound, the OP3 on performance/smoothness. Still too early to call on battery life and camera, but I'll update after a couple more days.
Long version:
I got a OnePlus 3 recently and its a great phone. My bf recently shattered the screen on his phone (an older Samsung) so my inner gadget-freak saw this as a reason to try out the Axon 7. Even thought I really liked the One Plus 3 I was drawn to the thought of having a QHD resolution screen again and I also liked the Axon 7's emphasis on sound because I listen to LOTS of music at work. And, it didn't disappoint in either of those areas.
It just arrived late yesterday evening, so here are some initial impressions of how the two compare:
Hand feel: The Axon 7 feels noticeably chubbier and heavier in the hand, but not by a bothersome amount. The Axon's curve fits into the palm well, so overall I'm happy with it too.
Screen: Both have vibrant/colorful screens, but the Axon's higher resolution gives it an edge in terms of everything looking just a touch smoother. (I tend to hold my phone pretty close to my face when using it). They each have some screen color/warmth adjustments in the settings, and the Axon's looked better to me when I was done. I am guilty of liking unrealistically vibrant screens and the Axon on 'Gorgeous' setting was happy to oblige. 
Sound: External speakers: No contest, the Axon is amazing, and Dolby Atmos was surprisingly good at adding distinct stereo separation and even a bit of pseudo-surround. No contest here in terms of which phone I'd rather watch videos/TV on.
Sound: Headphone: closer call here. The OP3 (after an update done a few weeks ago) is noticeably louder on headphones than the Axon, but the Axon's sound is richer overall. Once again I was pleasantly surprised by Dolby Atmos. Normally I keep that kind of stuff off, but after messing around with it a little bit I was able to create a custom sound setting that I *really* liked.
Speed: The OP3 has an edge here. Both were very smooth in general use, but the Axon has tiny hitches/delays more frequently than the OP3. Not anything that reached a point that it truly bothered me, but the OP3 is really outstanding in this regard, and the Axon is a bit less outstanding. (I've just been using MiFavor 4 so far, haven't tried alternative launchers yet to see how it does with those.)
Fingerprint reader: So far so good, both phones have fast/excellent fingerprint readers.
Camera: still tbd. First impressions are good. I've not yet had time to really explore the Axon's camera options. Some pretty intriguing settings I'm looking forward to trying, but haven't done anything extensive yet. I did a very low light shot that it made practically look like daytime, albeit a bit soft. Unfortunately I have lots to do tonight, so won't get a chance to take much time, but definitely will put it through its paces this weekend. I'll grab a couple shots at lunchtime and post those, but I'm sure it'll do well in broad daylight.
A few small sidenotes: I really like the ZTE Locker for lock screen wallpapers. It has some very nice ones and it's nice to have them randomly change each time I double-tap to look at notifications or just check the time. Both have useful gestures, I think it'll be very much individual preference as to which is better. Charging speed is very good with a quickcharge 3 plug. Battery life overnight was excellent. More to come after a few days use. The Axon seems slightly better at holding on to signal strength in marginal areas.

replies.text: Thanks for sharing your thoughts. I also have a OP3 and picked up an Axon 7 (it will be delivered tomorrow). The OP3 is blazingly fast, so hearing that the Axon 7 is a bit slower in that regard gives me some pause.

The OP3 really is exceptional in that regard. I wouldn't worry too much though, I'm being VERY picky when I mention the occasional hitch on the Axon 7. It's still very smooth almost all the time.....just a touch less consistent than the OP3.
Just remember not to judge it until you've finished churning through your initial app downloads. At first I was concerned until I remembered I was churning through > 100 apps being installed. Needless to say it was MUCH better once that was done.

How many app dl are you doing with the a7? 
How is the mifavor software vs Android?

Quick question. Is there a setting on the Axon that allows you to double tap the fingerprint scanner to turn off the screen and lock the device? I'm curious about this as it is a feature I use regularly on the OP3. Thanks.

At first run through I'm not seeing anything like that. You can control autolocking based on delay after the screen shutting off (anywhere from immediately to 30 minutes after), but I'm not seeing anything involving the fingerprint reader. The closest thing would be setting to autolock immediately and then tap the power button on the right side. Also, the Axon has the fingerprint reader on the back of the phone which probably makes that less appropriate, as you'd have to be holding the phone anyways to get to the fingerprint reader so it's just as easy to lock by tapping the side power button.
Thanks for that.
Does the A7 have an LED notification light?
Yes. Red or green is all I have seen.

I experimented a bit, and good news: I tested with the app Echo Lockscreen and it would light up the lockscreen on a notification's arrival (IF it is from an app you've set to allow to do that within Echo lockscreen). It also displays a summary of the notification without having to hit the 'bell' or any other icon, so it brings the notification screen's behavior closer to what you're used to.
Once the initial "light-up" has passed, you can double-tap the screen to show the lockscreen, and it will display the notification + details again w/o fully unlocking or tapping the bell. (The double-tap gesture is built-in to the axon, not due to the app. But, showing the notifications w/o touching the bell IS due to the app.)
Note: I've never used that app before, and just picked it at random, so no idea how it behaves long term, are there better apps out there, etc. Just a random test, but it looks like it does solve that issue for you.

After a couple days, some more observations: 
Bluetooth: One of my (few) frustrations with the OP3 was with bluetooth. It would frequently fail to pair on the first try with my car, and then sometimes I'd have to re-pair it, and sound volume was on the low side. I also noticed leaving bluetooth on would really suck battery life. 
So far the Axon's bluetooth has worked like a champ: pairs quickly every time, is staying paired, and sounds really good when listening in my car. No significant hit to battery life either.
Speaking of battery life, I like that their Power Manager settings screen does a good job of calling out misbehaving apps and applying settings (which you can override) like scheduled background wake-ups rather than letting them keep sucking away. It'll also let you know if they do things like 'Keep the System Awake' or 'Frequently Wake Up the System', as well as historical records of apps with high power consumption. Nice!

thread.text:
So turn it off.
I like being able to see a notification light, even if there's only red or green.
How does the battery life compare? Do they both comfortably get you through a long day?

I have a "rainbow snow" LG G4 right now that's going to be getting shipped off for warranty repair, but it's also an early run that's prone to the bootloop of death, so I'm anxious to replace it, since I've saved my nickels and have the budget for it now. I'm also flopping like a Magicarp between the OP3 and Axon 7. 
I'm leaning OP3 because of the software and camera, but part of me keeps screaming that the Axon has some better hardware. Radio signal strength between them seems fairly even, and not industry best either way, but the Bluetooth issue is something I hadn't thought of yet. I do use Bluetooth a lot, between my Moto 360, a BT speaker I use semi-regularly, a couple of pairs of Bluetooth headphones which are the only way I normally use headphones, and Bluetooth streaming/calls in my truck. If the BT is weak on the OP3 and better on the Axon, that may just be my deciding factor. 
I've also considered the Note 7, even if it's LITERALLY twice the price of either the OP3 or A7 ... but I just can't convince myself that the top notch camera, S Pen, and water resistance are worth it. I suppose I could just buy both the OP3 and the A7 and return my least favourite within the 15 day window ... but with delayed shipping times and my luck I'd probably get one 14 days before the other. LOL
On the camera side, I don't worry as much about low light and auto mode. I love the camera on my G4, but auto at night sucks. I go manual. The OP3 has the advantage of shooting in RAW, but they claim the A7 will be getting that in an update. A7 also offers 240fps slow mo video vs 120fps on the OP3. Not a major thing in every day life, but if I'm shooting slow mo, the more fps the better! 
It's great that phones have gotten THIS good at these prices, but good grief it sure makes it hard to decide what to buy!!

I haven't measured distance accurately for BT on my Axon 7 yet but I CAN confirm that it reaches my BT earbud by >30' and my stereo headphones by >25' and that's through walls in a house. My Mustang picked up the A7 and started Android Auto when I was in the garage for something and my phone was in the house. That was probably >30', through multiple walls and a brick wall. No complaints about BT range at all.
Just received my axon 7 6gb ram with 128gb inbuilt... Totally loving it.. Phone just flies.. Sold my S7 edge for Axon 7..so far so good...

What's everyone's favorite thing about this phone.

replies.text: Without question, the audio system with dolby atmos. Thats the reason I bought it.

I have two lines, I was using a Galaxy S7 Edge and a Moto X Pure Edition. I wasn't feeling the Moto X that much so I got the Axon 7 in grey.
I am now using the Axon 7 as my main device vs the S7 Edge. The main reasons are the stereo speakers, I prefer an all metal build, the rear finger print sensor (S7 edge is so low that I find myself unlocking it with the pattern vs the fp sensor), the overall look of the phone, I like the 3 pinch screen capture, quick charge 3.0 charges pretty fast , I really like the toolkit app package it comes with, I liked the sim/sd card slot tool keychain it comes with, the USB-C and the dual sim card tray. 
I'm really digging the weather widget it comes with and the voice and gestures controls. One of the commands I had been longing for a long time was the ability to control your music with your voice and this phone lets me! Like when I'm taking a shower or shaving or whatnot, I always have my phone playing music and it's nice to skip to the next song without touching the phone. I dig the stock notification sounds (I know these can always be changed but I never, I use whatever it comes with but I really the selections Axon made), pretty cool wallpaper selection. 
I kind of got tired of the no edges of the S7 edge and it lags a tid bit, so far I experience zero lag on the Axon 7. One thing I do wish the Axon 7 had that the S7 edge has is it being water/dust proof. I do prefer the stock messaging app the S7 edge has vs Axon 7 but I can always replace that with something else. I don't like that on stock operating system, the max # of apps width wise is only 4, so I'm using Nova Launcher on the Axon (actually on both).
I do think the S7 edge takes better pictures and I like the Always On Display, but overall, I'm happier with a $349 phone than a $750 phone.

Hey all, asking for some advice on how to protect my Axon 7's screen.
I've generally forgone these clear screen protectors mainly because they are a PITA to apply, and I ALWAYS have air bubbles and lint that get caught under there. Also never felt the need to bother with them because I was victim to the carrier scam having to buy a new phone every 2 years to justify the higher priced monthly service fees.
Now, I am on T-Mobile with an unlocked Axon 7 I bought straight out. I'm a bit more compelled to protect the screen on this phone since I plan on using it longer than 2 years.
It seems to me the two most recommended screen protectors are the tempered glass one, that people complain about because it doesn't fit the Axon 7's curved screen, and the wet Delta Shield one.
I'm leaning towards the Delta Shield, can anyone who has this one weigh in? Is it easy to apply? I saw on amazon there was a review that someone ruined their Axon 7 because some of the solution from the protector seeped into the speaker grill. Considering how much of an uncoordinated klutz I am, I can see this happening to me.
So anyway, what do you use to protect your Axon 7's screen, if anything?
The Delta works good on my Axon 7. No issues so far.

replies.text:
How was the installation? Were you concerned about that liquid getting into your speaker grill and ruining the phone?
I think I'm going to have to temporarily tape up the speakers before application.Thanks. The tape idea is a good one definitely.
Not worried at all, it's not like you douse it completely, just a mist to ensure it stays on. I did have a towel handy though.

thread.text:
First step before applying a screen protector - be in a dust-free environment.
Second step - wrap packaging tape (2" or 3" cellophane tape) around your hand inside out (glue side out) and pick up all the dust on the screen.Any screen protector is going to magnify a dust particle that you can't even see into a large bubble - even tempered glass shows some dust particles. But if you clean the screen first, the cheapest $2 glue-on plastic protector (I usually pay $5 for 3 of them) will work. (Mine have been on for over 3 years and don't show any bubbles.)

replies.text:
How was the installation? Were you concerned about that liquid getting into your speaker grill and ruining the phone?
I think I'm going to have to temporarily tape up the speakers before application.Thanks. The tape idea is a good one definitely.
Not worried at all, it's not like you douse it completely, just a mist to ensure it stays on. I did have a towel handy though.

thread.text:
Thanks everyone. DeltaShield worked out great. Before installing I taped over my speaker grills just in case. 
I really suck at installing these but the Delta was very forgiving. Since you install it wet, it's easy to move around and reposition after you place it on the phone. 
I had bubbles and crap even after using the squeegee, which was frustrating. But within 24 hours all of that went away and now you can't even tell I have a screen protector at all. 
A+ I'd recommend DeltaShield

I haven't used a screen protector since maybe the iPhone 2 came out. Never had any issues at all. I dislike that they eventually peel and collect lint and stuff on the edges. Just not worth it imo.

I just got my phone yesterday and noticed that with AT&T that my strength of signal on Wi-Fi and LTE is usually 2 bars lower than my honor 5x. Anyone else have this issue?
The phone losses signal altogether at times so I'm hoping an update can fix this.
Posted via the Android Central App

replies.text:
Don't use bars as your measure, go to your settings-status and look for your signal strength and measure with dbm numbers, in this case shown as -###, obviously lower is better because is a negative number.
Carrier phones has historically shown to show more bars on their phones compared to non-carrier phones but when you check the signal strength they are most of the times the same.
BUT, there may be some radios issues, so if signal strength is indeed worse, just ask for a replacement.

This is correct. The bars on your phone actually mean nothing scientifically, so they can't be used to compare signals

Unless I missed something, I haven't seen one person or credible reviewer mention any issues with dropped calls or voice quality on either end.
I just downloaded and installed "Network Signal Info" from the Playstore on both my Axon 7 and Galaxy S7 Active. I turned off Wi-Fi on both phones. The S7 showed a percentage of 50% , LTE, and a strength of -101 dBm. The Axon 7 showed a percentage of 46% and a strength of -110 dBm. I then reconnected WiFi. Wifi strength on the S7 was -40 dBm and a speed of 144 Mbps. The Axon 7 showed a Wifi strength of -38 dBm and also a speed of 144 Mbps. Yes, there is a difference, but not enough to cause any issues I would think.I ran speedtest.net on both phones and the result was nearly identical. It might be an issue for some users depending on their carrier and cell tower location, but honestly I see no problem here.

thread.text:
Does anyone else have a problem with their gesture feature where u shake your phone side to side to turn on the flashlight and not turn on?
If I go and turn on the gesture and asks me to try it out, then the flashlight turns on.
When I turn on the gesture and shake the phone it doesn't turn on.
Now when I turn on the flashlight and shake it, it will turn it off but not turn it on.
Any help would be great

replies.text:
From what I understand, the shake gesture to turn on the flashlight only works on the lock screen. So lock your phone, press the lock button to open the lock screen, then shake, the flashlight should turn on. You can shake again to turn it off or press the button on the on screen flashlight to turn it off.
It's not ideal but at least it's pretty reliable when on the lock screen. My previous Moto G device was able to use this gesture anywhere. Hopefully it'll get updated on the Axon to work this way.
