replies.text:
Yeah, it doesn't make much sense. If you are using your phone and you want the flashlight, you could always have it as one of the quick actions when you pull down the notification shade.
A better fix would be to have the gesture be recognized all the time, regardless of what the phone is doing (like how Motorola has it implemented). Hopefully it can be added in a software update.

title: Axon 7 Mini - Review - is it worth the $200? (got it on sale black friday)

thread.text:
So I've had the pleasure of using the Axon 7 Mini (gold variant) for the passed 12 days as my daily driver. I put my Galaxy S6 to the side and gave this puppy a try. One of my favorite phones was the HTC One m7 and I've been looking for a phone like it ever since so how was my experience?
First boot went pretty smooth and quick (unlike the pocket now first impressions which was a longgggggg first boot) I've installed the apps on it I needed most to see if it would be a good replacement to my S6 battery-wise
(apps include Instagram, note taking app, calculator, and a music game to test speakers)
I'm gonna have a good section and bad section for my review.
The Good----------- 
The phone ran smooth, not the fastest thing in the world but if you are just gonna go on instagram with it, watch a few videos and send some text messages you should be good to go. The phone was slower in other uses tho (seriously a game called opsu that doesn't use that many resources with settings turned down was dropping from 60FPS to about 27 and averaging around 44... unacceptable if you ask me... ran flawlessly on every other phone I've tried)
Speakers was AMAZING! I left my phone playing a song and went to the other side of my house and could clearly hear it, I went to a crowded mall and heard music from the speakers without issue loud as can be. No distortion at full volume
The fingerprint scanner was the quickest I've ever used, there is no point of a lock screen on the phone honestly you never see it.
Phone comes with dual Sim support and SD card support for those who use those features. I never use them so it didn't really add to my experience
1080p res was perfectly fine I watched a ton of YouTube and a downloaded movie with no issue colors were pretty good (I used high contrast mode in the settings) 
Phone charged pretty quickly, nothing crazy but faster than other phones I've used
Build quality was top notch! ZTE didn't skimp out on build quality that's for sure
Headphone playback was above average, louder than my S6 meaning it was more enjoyable (especially in my truck with the AUX)
The Bad----------
Like I said above the frame rate skipping is kinda crazy if you ask me, this wasn't some HD graphics intense game it puts up little circles you have to hit to the beat of the music so that was disappointing (note: i only tested 1 game I wasn't gonna use this phone to game with so I only tried something that made sense with the speakers
Phone call experience was horrible, I barely make phone calls but the few that I made was all bad experiences... the phone would lock up if you pressed the speaker option and not actually change to the speaker phone for like 10 seconds pretty crazy
When using the music app it would take about 5 seconds longer than another phone just to bring up the list (something that should be instant, I have 630 songs FTR)
the phone had a lot of stutters and app crashes (T-Mobile visual voicemail crashed on me at least 12 times and it never crashed on another phone for me) 
When plugging in headphones and removing them the phone would sometimes think they was still plugged in and not give out any audio unless you used the headphones or restarted the phone
the battery wasn't that great, there wasn't a screen on time viewer but I would estimate I was getting no more than 3hours 25minutes SoT (note: the phone does not come with a quick charger in the box)
the camera wasn't anything special, dull colors washed out images and blown out highlights (front camera was below average)
So was this phone worth $200? for sure! if they make another software update and fix some bugs yes. Would I say this phone is worth $300? no not at all. a lot better options imo
Who is this phone for? if you like hearing music without headphones, watching a lot of YouTube/media on your phone and primarily use texting/messenger apps this phone is for you. 
Do not buy this phone if you want to take pictures, videos or make a lot of phone calls on the current update it has
Have any questions? feel free to ask

replies.text: Ive yad mine since launch and its been great. Battery goes all day. Granted I carry it mainly for the media. But its a damn goid phone for the price. I've got the Axon 7 too. And very happy.

thread.text:
i don't know what fi is, but I've been using mine with Verizon for a few weeks now. it was a little bit of a pain because my previous phone uses a Micro-SIM card, and the Axon7 uses a Nano-SIM. i called verizon and told them i bought a new phone and needed a nano-SIM. they asked what phone i was getting and i told them Axon7 and the gal on the phone kept telling me it's not found in their "approved phone" list. i basically had to get firm with her and let her know that i've done the research and the phone takes a nano-SIM and to please send me one. 
i got it in the mail 2 days later. i popped it in and it didn't work. i then had to call verizon and told them i got a new SIM and needed it activated in my new phone. i had to read her the serial # on the side of the box that the SIM card came in, and the agent on the phone activated it and then it worked. i do have to keep it "roaming", but there is no roaming charges unless i leave the country, so it's been no problem. getting messages and phone calls just fine. also using LTE with no probs. the only downside i've heard of is that you can't access internet while using the phone, but i've never had to do that, so no prob for me. also heard wifi calling doesnt work either, but never used that either, so no prob for me.

replies.text: I just popped my Verizon sim into my axon7 and it worked flawlessly without me having to call VZW. I, too, noticed it on roaming. But like you, i never leave the goid old USA. my question for you is how do you know you're still on 4GLTE?

thread.text: Well I decided to try my ZTE axon7 with my Verizon sim card. Everything seems to be working fine. I'm receiving and making calls and texts without issues. Only noticeable thing is that an R, which i assume stands for roaming, appears next to my signal bars. Im wondering if that means I'm not getting 4glte. Anyone know about this. My calls ate clear. Internet working flawlessly.

Checking the specs, it HAS the correct frequencies and bands! EVEN the CDMA stuff. It should be fully working

You might also check your settings, under, the swipe down, then the settings cog, then More, then Mobile Network. Make sure 4G is selected, Data Roaming is turned on etc.

Its been a day and a half, and my axon7 is working flawlessly on Verizon wireless. No issues whatsoever. Calls come through clean, go through clean, no issues with sending and receiving texts. Data is fine. So if you want to stay on Verizon wireless and want as good a device as what they carry at a fraction of the cost, get the axon7 now while it's on holiday sale. It really is an awesome device. Especially if you listen to a lot of music.

replies.text: Don't lose confidence. It's basically a very good phone, especially at $400. I was going to sell mine, but have decided to keep it. Unless you actually have a defective phone, clearing the cache partition and/or doing a factory reset will solve 99% of the issues. I would at least wait until the next major software update to see what they can do.

thread.text: I have been using mine for several weeks without any real issues at all. There are a few strange non-working built in software pieces...but other than that, using Nova Prime launcher mine has never rebooted on its own and everything of importance works properly. So I would easily recommend this phone to anyone! Running on AT&T.

I couldn't agree more with jaseman. This is a good phone. Every single phone has some issues. I also have Galaxy S6 and S7's and they have issues too. Just read some of the forums here on virtually any phone. I too use Nova Launcher. If you don't like ZTE's apps, there are plenty of free 3rd party apps that will work just fine. So just enjoy your Axon 7.

The software stuff I have experienced is definitely due to a software bug. When I can't get apps to close but they are still up, that's a problem. In all my years of using Android phones, I've never had this happen. The phone rebooting is another issue that I have experienced and has really worried. It'll happen randomly while on a call or while it's sitting on my desk at work. 
I'm going to pick up a 7 plus on Friday and see what ios have to offer me because I like having both platforms.

replies.text: Try OP3. I debated between Axon7 and OP3 and went for later. It's just great.

thread.text: I fully agree that apps should close properly and it certainly is not normal for the phone to randomly reboot. You may have to do a factory reset. If you do, don't restore from a backup. Before you add any apps, see if the ones that come with the phone close when you do a close all using the button to the right of home. Also, see if the random reboot is gone. If both issues are still there after a factory reset, then I would contact ZTE about a replacement.

replies.text: If it continues, I will be contacting zte about getting the phone replaced. Sadly I can't get it replaced yet since they don't have any in stock.

thread.text: That's awesome man

I've had zero random reboots on my phone. I use Nova Prime as well. About the only issue I've had is with my Exchange account calendar syncing properly. I've installed Microsoft Outlook app and it seems to have fixed it. The only problem is I hate Outlook's calendar widget. None of the other calendar widgets work. I don't miss a meeting since the Outlook app works ok

The Axon 7 mini is recommended for sale at 299 Euros. If the US pricing falls in a similar area, it's somewhat unappealing. I mean, sure you get a 5.2" device, but for about $100 more you get an SD820, twice the internal storage, and a 2K display.
People may not notice the difference between the two displays, but the better SoC and storage may be worth the price difference.
What do you all think?

replies.text: The reason I'm considering the mini is to use for music listening. I carry a galaxy S7 EDGE, music through headphones ok, but not great. I've also expecting my pixel on Monday, but again, not expected for great music listening.

Well I received my mini today. First thing I said, wow, this is a mini? . Anyway, the only problem I noticed was the lengthy boot up time. Literally took about 3-4 minutes. But other than that, no hicups. I'll have more after I play with it this weekend.
Now that the first boot is out of the way, does it boot up any faster? I have noticed when flashing new ROMs (either stock or custom) the first boot usually takes a while.
To be honest, I haven't turned it off and tried it yet. I'll post later today.

Update-after the first boot, its only taking about 20-25 seconds to boot up. It's hard to believe this only has the Qualcomm 617. While certainly not like my pixel or S7 EDGE, its still remarkably quick.

After a couple of days with my mini, I've got to say I'm totally impressed with this device. For the processor it has, it's still pretty fast. Not like my pixel or S7 EDGE, but fast enough. The build quality, screen are top rate. But the reason I did buy it was for music listening. With that dolby atmos, its second to none. Even if you need a great phone without breaking the bank, this is it.

thread.text:
Yes the processor and memory differences are probably enough for most people to chose the regular 7 for $100 more. But I do find other advantages besides the savings that may make it more desirable to me personally: includes FM radio (I sometimes listen to FM while out exercising without data streaming) <--- Caveat: this feature is not listed on zteusa.com but only stated on various reviews, so must be confirmed. I prefer the 1080p display, finding it sharp enough and would rather preserve battery, cpu, and $ cost over a higher resolution panel 5.2 inch size might be sweeter spot for one handed operation as compared to the 5.5 incher
If I could buy right now I would strongly consider it, but I cannot wait long, especially when the Moto G4 Plus is available with similar specs and larger screen. The Axon 7 mini looks like a better travel phone than the Moto G4 ( wider LTE coverage between US and rest of the world) so it is on my short list if I can determine when it will ship.

replies.text: The mini is now in stock at b&h. Great pkace to buy. Free shipping too.

thread.text:
I picked one up from Best Buy yesterday to replace my Moto X Pure that was having speaker issues during any kind of audio playback that didn't involve the headphone jack and display flickering during gaming. It was between this, the G4 Plus (2gb/16gb), a Nextbit Robin, and a used S6/S6 Edge and decided for the Axon due to the build (I like metal), audio quality, NFC (I enjoy Android Pay) and the AMOLED display. I was reluctant to get the gold variant but isn't super gaudy like the Galaxy lines.
Didn't have the long initial boot as I've seen or heard, but the UI took a second to figure out. With Nova Prime it's easier to deal with. Not as quick as the X Pure but runs cooler. Noticed today that it has a reversible UI somewhat like Alcatel. 
The only negative I have is the lack of bass when playing through my car audio system by AUX cord since I'm used to the HTC One A9, LG V10 and the X Pure. Also wish they would have included a USB-C adapter, since I have like 4 10' Kevlar wrapped Micro USB USB cables.
All in all, I'd get another.

replies.text: I agree, im not having the bass problem at all. I fine tuned my dolby atmos. Holy crap what a sound. Im using my klipsch heresy speakers powered by a vintage mcintosh ma6100 amp. Awsume too on my bose QC3 headphones.
Have you had any random reboot issues? Mine is working flawlessly except it randomly rebooted a couple of times since I've had it. I wouldn't have even noticed except for the restarting chimes.
Nope, not even when I push it. I also have a scheduled power down and restart, so that may also be a reason I haven't experienced that issue.
It seems like it reboots when in completely out of any typ of connection, both data and WiFi
I'd try exchanging it for a new one, may be a device by device case which is unfortunate.

I was using an app called fi info. I noticed that I was loosing connection when it tried to change carriers. So I uninstalled. Its been fine ever since. Ive got a fi data only sim in the mini, so it stays connected to T-Mobile.

Network Performance and Connectivity
The Axon 7 is an unlocked phone with full compatibility across all major US carriers. It supports GSM, CDMA, HSPA, and LTE bands 1/2/3/4/5/7/12/13/17/20/25/26/29/30/41. Only the Motorola G4 Plus$329.99 at Amazon, G4$149.99 at Amazon, and Apple iPhone SE$399.99 at Verizon Wireless feature such broad network support. I tested the phone primarily on AT&T, but I was able to use data and make voice calls on Verizon as well. Network performance in midtown Manhattan was in line with what I've seen on other recent AT&T devices. The phone also supports dual-band Wi-Fi and NFC.ZTE Axon 7 Review & Rating | PCMag.com

title: Officially the worst phone I've ever owned

thread.text:
This is quickly becoming the worst phone I've ever owned (and I've owned a LOT of phones, including that Nokia abomination back in the 00s with the weird rotary dial pad).
This phone, however, takes the crown:Speaker often emits a series of pops when playing sound. Sometimes doesn't.Randomly stops playing music/podcasts when the screen turns off. Sometimes doesn't.The volume up/down is where any normal-sized human's thumb would go, and I find myself constantly turning the volume down when I mean to turn the screen on or off. I actually have to bend my thumb uncomfortably, or tilt the phone away, to hit the power button.The nav keys aren't lit in any way, meaning I'm randomly stabbing around the bottom of the phone to go home or back.
I really wanted to like this phone, but it is just an exercise in frustration to use it, even after a couple weeks of using it daily.

So don't be upset I think you didn't like the phone from the start... 
I really love mine, and that love grew as the days went by. Now I adore it

I use the built in email app for my work email. Today while I was at lunch I deleted about 15 emails from my inbox. When I returned to my office those emails were still in my desktop inbox. I synced the desktop thinking that maybe it had disconnected somehow but the deleted emails remained. Has anyone else had issues like this. I've had my phone for a few weeks and this is the first time this has happened.

First, read https://help.aol.com/articles/what-i...-pop3-and-imap and see which account type you have. If the account is IMAP (GMail accounts are by default, but your work email could be either), deleting the emails on one device doesn't delete it on other devices. (The email administrator could have changed the type of email server - it's just [usually] a check box - without realizing the repercussions the change would have on you, the user.)
It's an Exchange server.
Turned off sync for email, kept the contacts and calendar. DL'ed Blue Mail to handle the mail part.
My hotmail account works fine.
Blue Mail has its own issues. Set up my Exchange acct in the Gmail app. Looks good, works good.

thread.text:
I have this problem as well, and it goes away temporarily with a reboot, as you already discovered. But it will return at some point, if my experience is any indication.
After diving into it, the problem seems to be that the phone decides to squelch the notifications from the app. If the app is not able to "run" in the notification space, it stops playing.

thread.text:
Maybe it is just me but whenever I am typing out a text message, I get a random period that ends a sentence and then the next word is automatically capitalized. Quite annoying, although it does make me proof read before sending.
I have noticed it on the Swype, Swiftkey, Google and the ZTE keyboards.
Does this happen to anyone else?

Is there a chance you are hitting the spacebar twice? Some keyboards or messaging apps will interpret 2 spaces as a sentence end, and drop a period.
ETA:
In Swiftkey Settings, go to Typing & AutoCorrect, and you will see a setting for "Quick Period", and another setting for "Auto Capitalize". If both of those are on, you will experience the behavior you describe.

title: Stupid mistake: how to restore the memory saved after waking from lock screen

thread.text:
Hello all 
Stupid question after a stupid mistake from my side. 
You know, when you lock your screen and you wake up the phone, I used to have a pop up window telling me how many applications had been closed after locking up the phone, and how much memory had been restored. I accidently clicked on the "Do not show again" thingy. 
I was wondering where in the settings I could have this information back. I searched and searched but didn't find anything, so I'm wondering if one of you had the answer 
Thanx in advance for all your replies

Step 1: Head to the Settings menu. This can be done by tapping the cog icon in your notification shade.
Step 2: Find Apps (or Applications, depending on your device) in the menu, then locate the app that you want to clear the cache or data for.
Step 3: Tap on Storage and the buttons for clearing the cache and app data will become available (pictured above).

hello jaydenorr839 
I don't understand. I just want the pop up window back, the one that used to say when my A7 would wake up "Those apps (and the icons would show up) have been closed during the lock" so that I know which app are still used but closed.

Hello,
I've just got my Axon 7 last Thursday. I had before a One+One and I was pretty happy with it, but I'm a geek so when I saw the Axon, well... 
So on Thursday, when I first started the Axon and got the message "Do you want to reinstall your apps"? I said Yes and all the Apps I had on the OnePlus got installed on the Axon right away. Mistake?
During that first installation, the battery of the Axon went down like crazy. From a 100% (I had slow charged it the night before), it went to 5% in 3 or 4 hours. Got quite hot too. So I figured: "lots of work, let's see later" I charged it with the charger right after, fully.
The next day was fine. But I'm not a player, my main uses are the social apps (Facebook, Twitter), some text messages, one phone call that lasted 15 mins, web browsing, and some pictures (like 10) at night without flash. Got home last night with 10% left. Figured it was ok. So I charged it fully again.
This morning, waking up, the battery is at 80%. I haven't touched the phone... GSam says that Mobile Radio used 48% and the screen 34%. I activated the WiFi when I woke up and GSam says 18%. 
I didn't have that "issue" with my OnePlus so... 
My mobile network uses 4G but with my OnePlus, inside my home, I would only have something like H+ or rarely 3G.Maybe the mobile network is draining the battery. Since I haven't rooted the Axon (is it possible? I'm not too found of that), I can't used apps like WakeLock to see if something else is draining the battery...
I have installed of course the latest update from ZTE.
What do you think? Should I do a factory reset and restart from scratch, not reinstalling automatically the apps? Those are pretty basic apps btw, like I said no games, nothing fancy...
Or... do I have a faulty battery?
I chose this phone over the OnePlusThree because of its battery, I would be quite pissed if I had the only Axon with a defective battery 
Thanx for your help and comments

I just sold my Axon 7, but I used it for the past 2+ months and one of the best thing on the phone is the battery life, standby for me was one of the best, so for me in your case is one or various apps causing issues but do something, do a Backup of your phone using the WeShare app that comes pre-installed and at least save your Messages, Call History and other basic settings, it can do a "Full Backup" but i don't think that it will be a good idea to restore from a backup with a possible issue. After your backup do a Factory reset, clear your System Cache on Recovery Mode ( I always do that first) and then set it up as a new phone, once you finish restore your basic settings and then re-install your apps.

Here are a list of things I like more on the iPhone 7+ over my Axon:
Battery
Camera

thread.text: iOS is much more efficient. That's why

To me what makes IOS good is that it is proprietary. What makes IOS bad is that it is proprietary. 
If any other "Android" phone had it's own proprietary OS I suppose that phone would run better than any other "Android" phone.
So for now there is really only two OS's available for cell phones. I am not including Microsoft!
So if you want the smoothest and "possibly" the most stable, without the ability to make it your own, then go with IOS.
However, if you want to be able to customize to your hearts content, then you want Android. It may not be quite as smooth, though I think it is when setup properly with a good launcher like Nova Prime, and Android might not be as stable, but we need to remember that IOS runs on ONE brand of phone exclusively, whereas Android runs on...how many different brands of phones????

iPhone does run pretty good but I have never been a fan of their animations. Also, the home screen is the most boring thing out there. I have been tempted several times to go back to iPhone (I used an original iPhone and then a 4), but when I borrow my sisters iPhone for a little bit, I am already begging for Android after 5 minutes. And it is like he ^ said, iOS runs on one platform, where Android runs on multiple platforms and in many different forms. iPhone blew android out of the water 2012 and prior but I now think Android is now miles ahead.

Up until about a month ago, I was solely in the iPhone camp for the past 9 months. iOS is very easy and stuff works well. However, it does get boring if you're one to want your phone's OS to keep you entertained. Being able (required?) to customize suits me just fine. I've never had a stock, out-the-box Android experience that I've liked but that's likely because I'm able to customize to EXACTLY the way I like to.

thread.text:
Well we could all just keep speculating, which is fun for a while, or we could go out to ZTE website and read the actual warranty: https://www.zteusa.com/passport/
Where we can find this:
7. Premium Protection Plan
ZTEUSA provides a free–of-charge Premium Protection Plan with the purchase of every AXON device. This means there are no insurance premiums or monthly fees. The only cost to the consumer will be a deductible charge of only $79.99 USD for each claim. The Premium Protection Plan covers incidental consumer damages related to handling issues such as an accidental drop, minimal liquid exposure, or overuse conditions (i.e. cracked LCD, some forms of water ingress, USB connector damage, etc.). Intentional damage and misuse are not covered. The coverage period for the Premium Protection Plan is twenty four (24) months from the original date of purchase. Policy coverage only applies to the original purchaser and is not transferrable to others. Please refer to the Premium Protection Plan for further details.
Thxs alot bmonday
So, technically it's not free. You have to pay $80

replies.text: No it's free. You have to pay a deductible though, which seems good to me.

Technically the warranty is free, as in zero money. If you need to have a repair done under warranty, the deductible is $80. If you never need it you will never give up any money compared to other warranties that you pay a set amount every month for and if you don't need it you have spent money for nothing.

thread.text: For issues covered by warranty, there is zero cost. They even pay for shipping both ways. The deductable only applies if it's one of the conditions that falls under the premium protection plan. I had a similar plan with Samsung, and I had to pay an up-front fee to get the plan, PLUS a deductable every time I used it.
So I guess the way to put it is the warranty is free as is the Protection Plan. The only cost is if the Protection Plan is used for something that is not a warranty repair.

I really like that warranty plan, will definitely save me money long term from paying for AT&T's horrible coverage or even Square Trade!
Can't wait to get mine!

IMO very generous warranty plan. Carrier plans charge you a monthly premium + high deductible should you use the warranty. Squaretrade charges an up-front fee and deductible. With this, it's just a deductible, and $80 is a pretty low one at that for a smart phone.
Using their bootloader unlock utility voids it though, so be careful.

After doing some preliminary research and thinking that I would purchase an Axon 7, I was stopped cold by lack of FM Radio support. Why does Axon and other relatively high end smartphones not include this basic functionality? I might assume it is due to cost, except that the less powerful Moto G4/G4-Plus has it. I am currently using a maxed-out-spec Asus Zenfone 2 but the WiFi interface has become unreliable/unusable so I am compelled to purchase a new phone. I have not totally abandoned Asus products or the brand but I will not reward this phones failure by purchasing a new Zenfone 3.
I realize that FM radio is antiquated for some users, but I like to listen to the news or sports as I go for a walk or exercising at the community gym without having to pay for a 3g/4g data stream for over the top radio. Radio support could almost be considered a safety and security issue, as we recently lost power during a hurricane, initially relying on the smartphone radio to provide updates on local conditions.
I will give this issue more thought, but now I am leaning back to the Moto G4 and doing more research of other phones. Since I consider FM radio support to be more important than NFC or a fingerprint scanner, even though those later 2 features capture a lot of the headlines.
FM radio requires a chipset that includes it, and the manufacturer may prefer a different chipset - that doesn't include it.
I considered ir to be more important than water resistance but have accepted that I'm a minority, I think you're part of an even smaller minority since I've never heard that complaint

Having a better and flexible interface to control the TV and entertainment system would be nice, so IR blaster support would be much appreciated. Though I have seen that offered on phones so infrequently that I have ceased to think about it. 
During the hurricane outage I found my old thumb drive sized FM radio which still works well enough, I just don't want to carry an extra device. The ultimate personal mobility device, the automobile, includes a FM radio without question. But when traveling by foot one need to bring their own, even when already carrying a pocket computer capable of receiving other radio frequencies.

title: A few thoughts on the Axon 7

thread.text:
Discussing this phone in another thread and wanted to post a couple of pictures comparing the Axon 7 to the Note 4. Pictures taken with a LG G4. WD-40 is just to give a known color reference.
The color seems to change pretty dramatically when the screens are on in the pictures. The phones are on plain white copy paper.
Some other thoughts to go with this:
1> My carrier is AT&T, I have no issues to this point using LTE with the sim in either slot. I'm not sure if it does it on the Note 4 or the G4 but when I am on a phone call the icon changes from LTE to just 4G. I am still able to browse etc while on the call.
2>Battery life has been very good for me. ending my day at about 35%. My normal day of use puts both the G4 and the Note 4 at 10-15% or less, sometimes needing a bit of a charge, to make it through the day from 5AM to 9PM.
3>I have had zero random reboots that I am aware of. Since I listen to a bluetooth headset for music during my work day I would know if one happened during that time but at night I would not be aware of one.
4>Speed of the unit is quite zippy. The UI comes with two launchers built in, the MiFavor one and the Stock Android one. I normally use Nova Prime and have experienced no lag or stuttering that I can see.
5>Fingerprint scanner to unlock the device has been flawless and very quick...almost instantaneous.
6>I have not used the camera very much but the pictures I have taken have turned out satisfactory.
7>There has been no skips or pops in the bluetooth music streaming that plagued my Note 4.

Hi everyone,
I'm looking forward to purchase an nice piece of hardware and the Axon 7 is a top contender for me. I doubt about picture quality. 
All the blabber about the high quality hardware, low quality software of the camera have me puzzled, because it seems so problematic to the commentators. I thought this "problem" had an easy fix: I'm I mistaken if I believe I can just download any camera software (like Camera Zoom FX or Google stock camera) and enjoy better quality if the stock camera doesn't work well? 
Do I need an underlayer that will deal with the inner workings of the actual installed hardware at a low level? If so does it exist and how do you do it? Would such a manoeuver affect other capabilities such as interconnectivity with other apps, or with video management or even void the garantee?
Thank you for your support and help in my decision.
Simeon

Typically, a phone's camera quality is most hard coded inside the camera sub-system and not because of the camera app in question, so a new app may not get you a better picture. And the stock app is often your best bet since it was designed for the hardware in question.
There might exist some system mods out there that might eek a slightly better picture, but the improvement will be marginal. The only way for things to improve in any meaningful way would be for the OEM to update the imaging system software in some future update.

Thank you for your quick and clear response. Appreciated.
- Simeon

There were some note 4 roms that noticeably improved my camera, but the improvements were baked into the rom and not just a play store download. I'm hoping the axon community hits those heights, maybe if enough of us pledge to pitch some of our hefty savings on the phone towards devs...
By the way, a number of people on XDA are swearing by the Snap Camera app. I tried it and it does seem to produce better pictures than the stock camera app.

Signal is inconsistent. I'm not talking about the bar since a lot of carrier phone don't have honest bar. I'm talking about the signal strength. I have extremely fast data connection on my old Note 3 but when I'm using this Axon 7, my connection speed is barely faster than my home internet which is barely faster than dial up. But that not the only problem. I went down to a place with extremely good T-Mobile signal and got a full bar on my phone yet I can't even watch a whole Youtube at 720p without buffering? We are not even talking about 1080p or 1440p resolution here. 
This is my only beef with this phone cause I love everything else about it.

replies.text:
Have you done today's update? If not check in Settings-Updates to see if your phone is ready for the OTA and do it, it seems to have fixed most of people's concerns about connectivity. After you complete the update go to Settings-Storage and clear Apps cache, then turn it off and Press Volume up and power buttons until you see the ZTE splashscreen to enter Recovery Mode, once there, do a Wipe Cache Partition and reboot.
See if it's better.

I did not know about that. I just got my phone on the 15th so I figure it is already up to date and I remember my phone updating when I first turn it on. If I do the whole reboot with the wipe cache partition and reboot, would everything on my phone be erase?
Update: When I get to the splash screen, the moment I let go off the power and up button it goes back to the regular Axon screen so I can't do the whole reboot with wipe cache partition. Thanks

The update was released Sunday night early Monday morning so if you got it on the 15th and didn't update it yesterday then just do the update via the settings menu. 
About the Wipe Cache Partition, no, doing this won't erase any settings or apps. 
Turn it off and press volume up first and don't let it go, then press the power button while keep pressing the volume up and in about 5 seconds you should have the ZTE splash screen and you can release both buttons and if done correctly it should enter the Recovery mode, just remember that you are doing the Wipe cache Partition not the Factory Reset.

I figure it out. It actually made the phone slower. My download speed using my data was 2 mbps according to speed test, but now it like .50 mbps. Not sure why that is? In any case, both speed are extremely slow to be able to do anything other than basic web browsing. Do you have any other idea? I was so excited when other people said their signal improve but that not the case with mine. Thanks

No it didn't. All the update did is add more bars to the phone. There are even more people now in the ZTE forum complaining of poor cellular signals and poor download speeds. Myself included. I bought 2 A7's and both went back due to poor camera and extremely poor cell receptions.

thread.text: With TMobile Arizona no issues here wifi or cell connection

title: is the Axon 7 rear camera any good for both photo and video?

thread.text:
is the Axon 7 rear camera any good for both photo and video? 
comparing to Galaxy S7 and iPhone 6S Plus.

replies.text:
Both of this areas WERE already covered in yesterday's update. I took a couple of pictures yesterday to see and they indeed looked a lot better than before. Remember that the Axon has the hardware for great pictures it has always been software, this has been proven by people taking Manual adjusted pictures and they look great.
I think their major issue was the focus and that's exactly what they targeted on this update and it seems to have helped, and they are still working on even more adjustments, so maybe it gets even better with next update.
About the Signal, they did work with the RF performance and for some people it seems to have helped considerable with the Signal Strength, for me, not needed as I have never had any issues with it, it has always had the same Signal Strength compared side by side with my S7 edge and my Wife's S7. They worked on the Algorithm to calculate the bars so now people complaining simply because they saw less bars than with another phone and not comparing real dBm Signal Strength can stop their uneducated whining, for those others that indeed had some Signal issues, it seems that the adjustments has also helped a lot.
All for all, a very good update, they still have some other things pending but they are listening and it seems that the next one may include finally the Nougat update, I'm guessing, plus the other things like the work with the Notification bell on the lockscreen.
How is the camera in low light and motion?

I just took a couple of pictures of my wife walking in front of me in my Living Room in low light conditions and neither of them were blurry and it automatically displayed a night mode or something like that on the display when taking the pictures and to tell you the truth, they looked quite good for the conditions above mentioned. 
I can tell you that it won't get to the point of a Galaxy S7 or Note 7, no matter the software adjustments, but it indeed looks a lot better than before the update, and like I said, they are still making adjustments for future updates so one thing is for sure, it should get even better than now, so for a $400 phone, this camera now can be really used in most if not all possible scenarios and with very good results. IMHO.

Pictures of your wife or its not true lol. I'm kidding.
That's good to know. I'm looking to buy one. I want the gray but I don't get why there's a premium charge.
I'm Glad to hear this.... I loved the phone, but the Camera before the update was frustrating to an individual with 4 kids. I may take a another look.

I understand about needing a great photo shooter when having a family and little children, as you may understand nobody will know exactly what your needs are and whatever is good enough for me may not be for you, but again, for the price, this phone is almost perfect, now with a better camera is even a better deal. It won't get to the Galaxy S7/Note 7 level on pictures, it lacks the hardware for that, but the one it has is a very capable one so with some Software adjustments they can make it a little better and that's what they are still working for according to their Dev team. Good thing is that they have their Passport 2.0 Warranty that gives you 35 days to return the phone to them for a Full Refund, you can try it, if you are not convinced, simply contact them and request the return authorization.
They are still working on the Software for near future updates, they are even working with Cyanogen to allow for a full new ROM for those that don't have problems unlocking the Bootloader and installing Custom ROMs, so we can always have an almost Vanilla Android version soon if that is your cup of tea.
Would you mind posting some low-light (post-update) pictures? Thanks!

The Camera is trash. Number 2 reason I returned it. Number 1 was the radio. With that being said, both of these areas are to be addressed in the Axon 7 Update. I just read about it this morning, You may want to wait until the update is tested.
Camera can not capture ANY motion. My pictures were often blurry, low light was horrendous, and even daylight photos showed a lack of detail. The lack of detail may be a result of its inability to take photos of movement, moderate shake may have ruined my images. It is not an S7 or Iphone. If you want that I suggest the Honor 8 (still falls a little short in capturing movement). Photos are definitely better with other devices, but the Axon is a bargain.

title: Why are there not more threads on the Axon7?

thread.text: Haven't people received their Gold Units from the Pre-Orders? It's pretty quiet around here which is kind of weird I would of thought there would be a lot of chatter and people giving their opinions.
Just got mine last night. I really like it except that it doesn't work on Verizon 😡
I ordered quartz grey so will have to wait a couple more weeks before I chime in. Do appreciate what others have to say so hopefully the comments pick up.

replies.text: I'm in the same boat and with other phones coming out I'm really anxious to hear what people think of this device.

thread.text: I'm waiting on more reviews

I've had my gold one since Friday and posted a few comments in another thread. I honestly don't think you will be disappointed at all assuming you've read reviews and know what to expect. The audio is good and the camera is outstanding in good light. I had no issues at all with the fingerprint scanner and I can't even get the one on my Galaxy S7 Active to work. You have to take into account you paid $400 for the device. I looked at the Idol 4S, One Plus 3 and Zenphone 3. I honestly think this is the better phone.
I'm another of the "waiting for Quartz" Club. XD
I'm waiting to make sure it'll work on verizon without a hiccup.

I had to get the gold because I'm an impatient child! 
Anyway. I REALLY dig the hardware. I'm still trying to get used to the software, though. Coming from a 98% untouched stock setup, it's no surprise that I am not used to it. 
I'm trying to figure out how to disable some of ZTE's Bloatware apps, but ones like Calendar and Messages won't let me. ZTE Locker, the app that pulls pics onto your lock screen is nowhere to be found. Not even in the settings page!

replies.text: ZTE Locker is under Themes and Wallpaper. Go into wallpaper and it is at the top.
Oh! Very nice. Thanks!
What bloatwares are you trying to disable?

Mainly the ZTE apps. Especially the ZTE Locker. I had to factory reset my device last night because it was trying to force a new wallpaper on my screen. After restarting it 5 or six times within 30 minutes, I gave up.
Posted via the Android Central App

thread.text: Waiting for my Quartz Grey one.

This phone is one of the best I have ever used. Except for some software changes that I have to get used to, it's amazing. The build quality is top notch.
Posted via Axon 7

I wish more people had the phone. Since it's not fully compatible with Verizon right now, it can't be on my list.
Posted via the Android Central App on the Moto X Pure Edition

I got mine today. It's an excellent phone, with a screen comparable to the S7 Edge, and audio that surpasses any phone I've used. So far, the down sides are:
It's WiFi and cell are both significantly weaker than my S7 Edge, and Nexus 6P (I got the 6P on sale last week and would keep either that or the Axon 7).
I'm using T-Mobile. I used speedtest to check the Wifi signal. It is the same strength as the other two phones on the same floor as the router, but one level down or up in our townhome, and the speed is less than 1/3rd of the other two phones. The Wifi signal also cuts out periodically on other levels on the Axon, but does not do the same on the other two.
I used an app called Network Signal Info Pro to check the LTE signal in my area. The difference in strength is -114db on the Axon vs. -101db on the Nexus 6P, with the lower number being better. Perhaps these are issues that can be fixed in a software update. I'll contact ZTE support tomorrow.
Posted via the Android Central App

replies.text:
Very interesting. Mine will be here tomorrow so if signal strength is an issue, I'll just get the Note 7.
Posted via the Android Central App

I seriously don't understand this type of thinking...if the Note 7 is on the table, why on earth are you messing around with an Axon 7? I figure the people going for this phone are the somewhat budget minded people that want something under $500. If you can pay that $850, get the Note 7, no question. That is a true flagship experience.

I think for some, like me, there are issues with every phone. It is just that some have more than others. If I found a device that did everything the S7 Edge did and made me happy, for half the cost, I would be thrilled. I would sell the S7E and keep the other device. What I have found, however, is that there is a reason devices like the S7E cost what they do. They do not have the issues the OP3, Axon 7 and other less expensive devices have. I understand that many people do not like Touchwiz, but for me it is a non-issue. I use Nova and disable the apps I do not want to use and Touchwiz is fine. In fact, Samsung has the best email, calendar, contacts and dialer apps out there, in my opinion. That includes anything available on the Play Store. 
I am still trying the Axon 7, but it will likely go back. There are just too many compromises. It is a good phone for the price. I agree with you, however, that spending the additional amount for the Samsung flagships is worth it for those who can afford it. They are the best phones out right now if price is not a factor.

I'm not trying to start a argument, but I don't think that the Samsung phones are are worth the extra cash. 
I took my s7 Edge back in a week and got another V10 knowing it's shortcomings on AT&T. I gave my note 5 to the wife to use to get my first V10 .. So truth be told.. We all are of a different mind about what we use... Lol
The Axion 7.. After much consideration will be my next phone and once they unlock the bootloader it's just a matter of time till it will be rooted and running the latest goodness available. 
I loved my HTC m8 boom sound speakers and sound quality and this one is sure to please, unlike my s7 edge that sounded like listening to a drowning cat over 2 tin cans and a string.. Meh... 
Quartz Grey next month for me and my son can have my 1 month old V10...
Posted via the Android Central App

I am a gadget nut and spend more than I should on devices. I have an S7 Edge. I still went for the Axon 7, because it appears that outside of the camera, it's actually potentially, on paper a better phone. This is particularly true if you're an audiophile.
While you can see above I've had some problems with mine, and I will replace it, I think this is a "mid-rangers" in price only. It's specs and feel are very high end. So if it costs less, that's even better. I can tell you that it's got the best audio though headphones that I have ever heard on a cell phone, and that includes the LG V10, and the HTC 10. The Dolby Atmos is phenomenal. I used Bose QC25 headphones to listen. It's speakers kill the HTC 10, and in my view are better than the HTC One M9's and the Nexus 6P.
I don't think I'm alone in considering this phone despite being able to afford more expensive ones.
Posted via the Android Central App
I'll trade you a ZTE Axon plus my headphones for a Note 7....

If you are someone that likes to buy more than one device, then I get it. It becomes more of a hobby at that point, which is cool. I was so happy with my HTC M7 for over two years, never even cared about what new phone was coming out. Finally it was getting too laggy and had to replace it. After trying out a ton of phones, I stuck to a 1+3. But I do miss those front facing speakers and thus the Axon 7 has perked my interest. I want to see what the new Nexus phones look like first, but maybe I end up giving this phone a go.

The only thing you have to understand is that everyone has different criteria when it comes to choosing a device. Apparently that gentleman is not concerned with price or high end "flag ship" status in his purchase decisions. He may place more value on materials, form factor, features, software, etc. He decided he wanted to shop between the Axon and the Note 7 and that's absolutely legitimate for him. He obviously likes both devices. So why shouldn't they both be on his shopping list? If you're implying that higher price means better or higher quality, then you'd be sadly mistaken. This Axon puts some "high end" expensive devices to shame. With it's cheap self!
Well, at least the Axon 7 doesn't explode...

I replied to you about the wifi on the other thread but didn't know the details of the LTE signal, that doesn't sound normal or at least similar to what I have read from other users and reviews where LTE signal was the same in a S7 edge and on the A7. In that case, remember that you have the great Passport Warranty or if you bought it from Amazon, or Newegg, they have excellent return services, I'd ask for a new one just to discard bad radios.

I'll probably do that. Thanks.
Posted via the Android Central App

Be really careful if buying from Newegg. If you read the product description it says the phone can be returned or exchanged within 30 days. But it also states the phone falls under the Newegg Standard Return Policy. This policy states no returns on a non contract phone. Only exchanges. I talked with Newegg today and was told that they will not refund the phone. They will only exchange it. I canceled my pre order due to many people reporting all sorts of problems with the A7. If I got a bum one I would want a refund not another phone. I wouldn't trust another one. Buyer beware.

Any problems with the reseller and you can always simply return it directly to ZTE within 35 days, this way is even more convenient as you can keep the Monster headphones that I already have sold to a friend for $60, if returning it to the seller you must return everything included with the purchase. 
I hope for the best but I'm really not worried, the great warranty program was what made it more attractive, and I may be wrong with the above, but I'm confident that in worst case scenario, everything should be covered this way.

I would like to hear from ZTE that this would be possible. This question was asked in the ZTE forum but so far ZTE has remained quiet and has not answered. Based on the Newegg policy and ZTE's silence I canceled my pre order. Might revisit the Axon 7 in the future if these questions as well as the promised software updates and unlocked boot loader are ever delivered.

Their warranty policy clearly say that you have 35 days from the day you buy it to return it (to ZTE) for a full refund. There is no indications that if you buy it via a third party vendor the return must be to the seller and not to them, I highly doubt they will leave themselves open for legal troubles because of this.
What it was confusing was that apparently some of the original vendors were not showing the Passport 2.0 warranty as part of the phone features so people were having doubts if that means that the warranty won't be available if buying from those sellers, but again, I highly doubt they will leave out 1 or 2 of their few resellers from their passport 2.0 program, anyways, Newegg is indeed one of their official reseller and Newegg even lists the Passport 2.0 full features on the phone description, giving the clear implications that it's covered for both, newegg return policies and ZTE Passport 2.0 coverage.What does the Passport 2.0 warranty cover?30 DAY TRIAL:
If you're not satisfied with your Axon phone, send it to us within 35 days of purchase and receive a full refund.

I understand what you are saying. But until ZTE comes out and answers the exact questions I'm not convinced and will not take the chance. Newegg is confusing enough saying they will issue a refund within 30 days but if you read the fine print in their return section they will not refund a non contract phone. Not taking the chance with ZTE until they answer the question themselves.
Edit
This has now been answered on the ZTE forum by a member who claims to be a ZTE employee. If you purchase your phone outside of ZTE then you must abide by the return policy of that vendor. So if you buy from Newegg you can not return the phone for a refund. With Best Buy it's 15 days only. B&H is honoring the 30 day return. If the phone is defective ZTE will replace it. But if it was purchased somewhere other than ZTE then ZTE will not refund the phone. You must follow the return policy of the place you bought the phone from.

Thanks for the info, but again, that's not what their policy states, plus before I decided to buy from Newegg I called ZTE and had a long chat with one their CSRs that talked with extreme confidence and seemed very knowledgeable of all my questions and she clearly mentioned to me that their Passport 2.0 warranty will be covering everybody, not just the ones that buy from them, like HTC does with their Uh Oh protection plan, and yes, that was one of my specific questions. 
Never trust what a CSR say via Forum, text, or phone, just look at the response to me and the one you saw in the forums, total contradiction, what matter is what is explicitly said on their policy and as you can see in the link I provided and in other news articles mentioning the Passport 2.0, they NEVER say that it just applies to purchased directly with them like HTC does. 
So, again, I hope for the best, and I know that according to past experiences my chances of getting a bad unit is always there but I want this device so if I get a DOA device I'll ask for a new one from Newegg, if I don't like it I'll demand their passport warranty and get my money back within 35 days like it clearly states if not, nothing that a good law suit warning can't take care of and in worst case scenario, there's always Swappa where I know I can always sell it for a profit, as the ones being sold right now.

thread.text: My signal strength bounces around more than the S7 Edge, but it is not that different as far as signal readings on AT&T. Maybe 1 or 2 db difference. Calls connect fine and sound very good. Wifi is the same as the S7 Edge.

With all of the iffy reviews that I have seen so far, with the pre-order date for the Quartz model being pushed back here in Canada to 9/9 and with the Note 7 launch yesterday I decided to cancel the Axon 7 and go with the Note 7. Out of pocket price will be about the same however I will be renewing my contract with the Note 7 to get that price. Not a huge deal for me as my company pays my monthly bill (They don't pay for my device though, sadly).
I see the Note 7 as having many extra features with the top ones I think that are important to me are water resistance and wireless charging, the others like S-Pen/iris Scanner/etc. are nice to haves as well.
Main reason I've gone for the A7 is the audio capabilities, the rest is a bonus.

I bought from Newegg and the phone is great! Not too concerned about low light photos since I don't take many photos anyway. I bought it for the build quality. I do not like the glass curves or the glass back on the new Samsung's. The new S7 to me looks like the S6 except turned backwards. Far too many people complaining about how easily it scratches and or breaks from minor drops and wear and tear. The lower price is just icing on the cake! I can easily afford a more expensive phone like the Note 7 but I still think, for my use the Axon 7 is the better phone.
30 threads for a ZTE phone is really good. I actually hope this brings some well deserved attention to the OEM.

After 24 hours with this device, I'm still trying to figure out how they're able to sell this thing at $400! I truly hope that this thing sells like crazy so it'll convince other OEMs to take notice. 
The hardware is spectacular. This thing flies and handles just about everything like a champ without turning into a pocket toaster. Playing music on this thing is making me blow the dust off of my old headphones. Signal reception seems about the same, WiFi seems to work better for me over my Moto X Pure. I don't really use the camera much, so I can't really talk good or bad about it. 
My only complaints is with the software. It could really use some fine tuning. It's mostly good overall, but the notification bell is annoying, ZTE Locker can be frustrating, and text needs to be lined up properly. 
The good news is that 95% of my issues can be fixed with updates. ZTE is planning on eventually unlocking the bootloader. If they do that, I might actually put stock Android on it. Not because I hate the MiPop UI, but I think this thing would be flawless with Stock Android. 
I don't think the positive reviews are over selling the device at all. It's way better than its price point would suggest.
Posted via the Android Central App

Did you put the SIM card in slot 1 or 2? Others have reported Verizon is working in SIM slot 1.
Posted via the Android Central App

The axon 7 is a true flagship. Without the cost. Its really a different phone experience and with that, the person who chooses it isn't looking fora pen and Iris scanner. Audio and metal build are more important. Maybe the cost is too but that's not why for me. I moved from the s7 edge because the UI is still laggy compared to a better optimized phone. To each his own.
Posted via the Android Central App

I just got my Axon 7 today. I'll report back in a few days but so far, so good. I actually like the software.
Posted via the Android Central App

This whole debate has me wondering if I should kill my pre-order. My understanding was that the 30 day return window was for any purchase. Since newegg is the ONLY official way to buy the phones in Canada, it seems odd that they wouldn't honour the manufacturer's policy. I guess I still have a few days to decide before it's too late. Might have to have a chat with newegg Canada. Part of my reasoning for ordering the Axon (because I was ridiculously close to ordering the OnePlus 3) was the 30 day return window. I figured that would give me time to decide if it was what I wanted or not. Hmmmm.
Edit: WRT the non-contract phone return policy at newegg - the Axon 7 does NOT fall under that policy. If you look at some of their other unlocked phones, they specify the non-contract phone return policy ... the A7 falls under the standard return policy. So basically, you can return it, but you'll get hit with a restocking fee in all likelihood. Even in the section where they list the Passport 2.0 features, they exclude the 30 day exchange line. Sooooooooo ... I don't know about that part. But it should be returnable, even if at a cost.

replies.text: A word of advise if I may, forget about the vendor's policy and just enjoy the phone, it's a great device, it really is a flagship at a mid range device price. BUT, if for any reason you want to return it, just return it to ZTE, their passport 2.0 covers Newegg sales, in fact ZTE themselves recommended me to buy from Newegg when I called them for a concern I had. If you read the passport 2.0 information they don't mention that the 35 days return windows is to the vendor you got it from, it's implicit that is to be returned to ZTE, so in worst case scenario and you have any issues with Newegg you should just contact ZTE directly and return it to them for a full refund providing you the Sales invoice or receipt.

thread.text: It's good advice. I don't expect that there will be any issues, but I do dislike there being multi-layered and consumer-confusing policies at play that seem to contradict each other in some ways. The "official" vendors should honour the OEM's policies as offered. If that's a 35 day no questions return policy, that should be across the board, and not subject to a vendor's own plans. Don't confuse and complicate things for the potential customers - or, as we've been reading already, they'll simply not buy it and get something less confusing instead.

I'm not sure what is happening, but last night I powered my Axon 7 completely off with the battery at 100%. This morning I noticed it was on, very hot and the battery at 77%. So, it turned on by itself and proceeded to drain the battery. I powered it off again, set it on a table. It turned itself back on and is now stuck at the "ZTE powered by Android" screen. Holding the volume down and power button does nothing. I had a buyer on Swappa and had to cancel the listing. Of course, I'm past 30 days with Newegg so I will have to send it to ZTE. No one else has so far posted a similar problem , but i just wanted people to be aware if yours does something similar. I'll post later how the exchange goes with ZTE if anyone is interested.

replies.text: Correct me if I'm wrong but what I can get from your post is that the phone got very hot and the battery drained a lot more than it should. Sorry but that to me sounds just like typical behavior when a rogue app, and a very bad at it, is causing havoc. Did you check the battery stats to see if you could see it there? I don't doubt that ZTE will replace your phone but to me it wasn't even necessary, trying to pinpoint the issue would be the best, the same can happen to your replacement if it was a rogue app and you end up installing it again.

I agree as it sounds like a rogue app as the phone has been fine for a month. About a week ago I powered the phone completely off. When i turned it back on a week later the battery was completely depleted. That was my first clue something was wrong. I charged it up to 100% and all seemed well for a few days. I did a factory reset yesterday as I was going to sell the phone. As I said, this morning I was surprised to find the phone had turned itself on from a completely powered off state and was actually soft-bricked. In my haste to try and fix the issue, I admit I forgot to check the battery manager. By doing the 3 finger salute, I finally got it to boot up. I've been using the phone all day today adding back apps one by one. So far, so good and battery manager reports "no power-consuming apps". I tried to install Watchdog Task Killer that I use on my Samsung and LG phones, but it immediately crashed upon installation and I had to remove it. I guess MiFavor doesn't like task killers at all. I'm going to power it off later tonight and see if it powers itself back on during the night. I have had rogue apps heat up a phone before, but never wake up a phone that had been powered off completely. I'll see how it does between now and Monday and call ZTE if it happens again i guess.

Remember that this one of the few phones that have the feature to schedule power off and power on instances so if some rogue apps corrupt that feature or is involved with it somehow it can explain the unexpected power on. 
I agree that it's very strange and if seems you have done your work on trying to find and fix the issue, I was just pointing out the rogue app theory as you didn't mention it in your OP. Like I said, you should be good worth ZTE with a replacement after explaining everything you have explained here, good luck.

thread.text: Keep us up to date. That sucks.
Never heard of a rogue app. Interesting

replies.text: Any bad coded app or simply an app that its intentions is to cause havoc can create such a mess that sometimes a factory reset is the only way to fix it, kind of like a malware or virus on a computer. A lot of those apps are installed via 3rd party methods and even some of them get to the Play Store and are downloaded thousands of times before Google find out about it and remove it.

thread.text:
Anyone knows if this phone will work with a Sprint sim
Posted via the Android Central App
A lot of the material I see points to it not having CDMA radios... so no Sprint or Verizon.

The Axon 7 has both CDMA and GSM radios. http://www.phonescoop.com/phones/phone.php?p=5189
Posted via the Android Central App

replies.text: Cool... There were two versions of that phone.. the one that made it out to reviewers is an almost entirely different model from the looks of it.

thread.text:
It has the ability to work on Sprint (and Verizon) network but first Sprint needs to flip a switch on their end to make this happen. No word yet if/when this will be done.
Posted via the Android Central App

replies.text: What "switch?"

thread.text:
Just Sprint activating it.
Posted via the Android Central App
In theory, if a compatible sim is already active on the account, a simple sim swap "should" work. Do it all the time. But we'll see.

replies.text:
On Sprint or Verizon?
Posted via the Android Central App on the Moto X Pure Edition

That's not exactly how Sprint works. It's not as easy as just swapping the SIM. They need to first allow the device on the network so you can activate it here. With Sprint your SIM doesn't really matter that much (it's just used to access LTE) you can swap to any Sprint SIM from that link. You can't add a device Sprint hasn't approved to the network.
Verizon is a little different. You can't activate an unapproved device on their network but if you activate a phone that is approved then pop the SIM into any phone that has the radios to use the network and it will work. AT&T and T-Mobile you just activate the SIM and pop it into whatever phone you want.

thread.text:
It doesn't work that way on the CDMA networks.
Posted via the Android Central App
Verizon.
It worked seamlessly on the Moto X Pure without permission. Maybe it would work out of the box. You might be without LTE Voice, but I imagine that you'll manage until it's official.

No idea. All I know is that, like my Moto XPE, the phone has all it needs to work on both GSM and CDMA networks but Verizon and Sprint, unlike T-Mobile and AT&T, need to do something on their end to make this happen. Plenty of discussions about this already.
Posted via the Android Central App

replies.text:
In the case of Verizon, because of the 700 MHz auction, they need to accept devices that use that band. In theory, like the recent Nexus phones, last year's Moto X, and this year's Moto G, SIM swaps should be sufficient - no need for Verizon to do anything.
In the case of Sprint, Sprint doesn't have to abide by those rules.
Posted via the Android Central App on the Moto X Pure Edition

thread.text: Not perhaps entirely deserving of the term 'Mini', this will nevertheless be a welcome alternative to the full-size model for the smaller-handed user. Small bezels keep the overall size on the low side.Hands-on with the ZTE Axon 7 mini | Android Central

Got my Axon 7 in Quartz Gray yesterday. Wow! What an incredible phone! I only have a few very tiny gripes overall and most are with Axon, not the phone itself.
The box was the standard Gold Trim box and gold accessories. I would have preferred Gray but that's a very small gripe. One of my biggest gripes overall is that I ordered from Axon so I got a free Flip/View case. When I pulled it out the box, it is Gold. Not very happy about that. Had I known that, I would have ordered elsewhere because I am not going to use a Gold case. I may contact them and see if I can return it for something else.
The navigation keys REALLY need to be backlit. My solution would be for pop-up screen buttons when the light sensor detected a very low light level. It's another small niggling point. Not major, just an observation.
Setup was fast and very easy. Transferred everything from my S6 Active and got all my accounts synchronized. Didn't play with the camera much as I was too busy being amazed by the sound from the speakers which was one of the major selling points for me.
The phone is quick but it does hang in a few spots. (Thought it may be learning.) I noticed that opening my USAA app takes a couple seconds where on the Active, it was pretty instantaneous. The fingerprint sensor is AMAZING and I set it as security for all of my banking apps that allow it and it works flawlessly. I am ultra impressed by it. 
The phone doesn't feel the least bit slippery to me like I had read. I put it in the clear case that came in the box with it and it's fine for my tastes until I find something better. 
The screen is GORGEOUS as reported.
Overall, I'd give the phone a solid 9.3 out of 10 for ME. Just a few tiny things like the lack of backlit keys, nothing major. For $400, I can't complain one bit!

thread.text: As per ZTE Community forums:https://community.zteusa.com/communi...say-bootloader
Like it  Good move ZTE.

And now people are freaking out that they have to give up their warranty coverage to get it unlocked.
Luckily, I doubt any of those people will actually be unlocked by ZTE anyway, those types are too likely to use the warranty return process to de-brick.

Not sure why they left Canada out lol only US.
Posted via the Android Central App

In Canada, we get the US version of the phone ... so same deal.
While I think voiding the warranty with an unlock is craptacular on their part, here's how I look at it. Odds are that I'm personally not going to do it anyway. I've had Nexus phones (my wife still does) and I've done all sorts of rooting, romming, flashing, tweaking, messing about. Then I went last year to the LG G4, and there is no bootloader unlock for it (yes, there is a model that's unlocked, but I don't have it). While my inner geek is sad that I can't mess around with ROMs and such on it, at the end of the day, I'm okay with that. I use the phone mostly for my daily life ... calls, text, messaging, snap some pictures, occasionally some video. Once in a while I'll take out the tripod and do some long exposure night shots/light painting ... but if I want to really get crazy, I break out my old SLR so I have aperture control too.
The two year warranty, and really reasonable 'deductible' for out of warranty repairs they're offering is quite impressive. 80 bucks for a screen replacement out of warranty? Hard to beat that! What makes the unlocked bootloader great, in the long term, is that if ZTE abandons software updates for the phone by the time that 2 year warranty is gone, hopefully there will be enough of a dev community there to keep the updates alive unofficially. That's the power of an unlocked bootloader in my mind. Not so much for the now ... but for the two years from now.
I'm also wondering, and might have to take this to the Z Community forums for an answer ... even if it voids the two year warranty - does the unlimited out of warranty repair offer still stand? IE: instead of two years of free repairs, does it become two years of factory repairs at the cost of the standard deductible? If that's the case ... still not SO bad.

title: How long will it take to update to 7.0 nougat for the axon?

thread.text:
To update to 7.0 nougat for the axon?
Here's a Na article I copy and pasted...
So instead of asking about the latest version of Android, we're asking about the new monthly security updates that Google is issuing. And the answers to that new, less ambitious but more important question are not good, asAndroid Central*pointed out in February. Now, buying a new Android phone demands that the consumer look into whether the manufacturer has committed to those monthly updates and if it has a good history of keeping that promise (so far: Samsung, HTC, and BlackBerry are doing pretty well, Moto and Sony are not).
Does axon keep up with these security updates?
As far as I'm aware they have a fairly poor track record, but the axon 7 is the first with the near stock ui, so it is supposed to be better I think.

A slight correction to that... I have last year's Axon Pro and it was actually closer to stock software than the Axon 7. They were pretty good as far as system updates went, with the phone getting Marshmallow in mid-february, sooner than most of the other "flagship" phones. The monthly security updates were a different story though. They would only bring them up to the current level when they would do a system or maintenance update. No updates just for the security patch. If I remember correctly, the phone has had two maintenance updates and one system version update, so not bad really. Unfortunately I've had a ton of unresolved issues since the jump to Marshmallow.
I watched ZTE's webinar about the Axon 7 and they kinda-sorta-but-not-really committed to keeping the patches up to date. He danced around the question suggesting that updates were important but monthly might be too frequent? I got the definite impression he had no idea Google did monthly security patches but then he was more of a marketing guy I believe?

One reason I like my Nexus line of phones.
Just not a fan of Nexus 6p

I'm GUESSING they will update to N fairly quickly once Daydream is announced, since they've been marketing the 7 as the first Daydream compatible device ... and they need N for that. They have confirmed (at least ZTE Canada via Facebook) that the N update is coming ... and I'm hoping when it does they address the main concerns of the community like the notification bell, improved software experience, and supporting camera RAW. If they nail that, there will be a lot of happy folks.
I haven't pulled the pin on my next phone yet. I'm between the A7, the OnePlus 3, and the Note 7 right now. Yes, the Note 7 seems out of place in that list, because for the same money I could buy both the OP3 AND the Axon. But the S Pen, camera, and IP68 really appeal to me. And it's within my current max budget. I just really, really hate glass backs. And I can't really justify the price on those three bullet points. The OP3 has the same strike against it that waiting for the new Nexus phones does - no microSD. It's something a personally use and love. 
Right now, out of the box, the OP3 still has an edge based on camera and software. They have done a stellar job with OxygenOS, and ZTE should really be taking notes from them on how to do Android right. Heck, ALL manufacturers should sit up and take notice there!

Really like the phone so far after a week but one thing that is beginning to happen is the dreaded reloading of tabs in my browser when I switch to and from other apps to it. I haven't run into this problem for years and the days of low RAM devices. I've been using a Note 5 previously for about a year and it never happened with that despite having the same amount of RAM. I don't even play games or use large apps and it is happening. I remember the first few generation iPads and Android tablets did this and I hated it. A waste of time and data. It will happen with just like 2 to three tabs open too. Anyone else seeing this? Do you think an update will fix this? And this is with Firefox. And it is not the app because I don't see this behavior on the Note using the same app.
I've had 10 tabs open and switched back and forth with no discernable slow down but I use chrome. Maybe it's something not playing nice in Firefox?

Does the phone come with any kind of "RAM Manager" app, or did you install a 3rd party one yourself? If so, uninstall or disable it, and see if the problem persists. A RAM Manager app might try to "clean RAM" (which is totally unnecessary) whenever you leave the browser, so that when you go back to it, it has to reload everything again.

replies.text:
browser.meta_refresh_when_inactive.disabled 
I just toggled the above setting in about config and that seems to have done the trick so far. It's just weird because I never had to do that on the Note 5.

thread.text: I take it back. Still happening.

Ordered one from Amazon thinking I did my due diligence, but the one plus 3 looks a little better...I like the audio on the Axon, but 80‰of the time I'm running thru a Bluetooth speaker...I'm using a lg g2 now, had it for a couple years, and it's been a damn solid phone for me. I like the A7, but there are just a number of settings that need to be added to compete with other devices. One that drives me nuts is getting notifications while on a phone call. Samsung struggled with this for years and finally added a setting that allowed the notifications to be disabled while on a call. I was just on a call and when an email came in. It buzzed in my ear, but the person on the other end also heard it. It is embarrassing. The email app needs to have a bunch more options to make it function like others (Samsung's is the best). Some call settings re missing (blocking numbers). The stock messaging app is a mess. The notification bell is just silly. When you indicate that you want to see notifications on the lock screen you should be able to see them. Block them if you do not want others to see them. 
The screen is very good and I have no hardware issues. Sound is good through wireless headphones and on calls. Signal is pretty good, slightly lower than the S7 Edge. Wifi and bluetooth seem to work fine. The buttons do not bother me at all. I have not really tried the camera yet, but do not expect much based on everything I have seen. I will try it out over the weekend. 
Overall it is very good, but there are a number of relatively small things that tend to add up to make it less enjoyable experience when compared to other phones. Time will tell if I keep it or not.

Found out something yesterday. This may or may not help someone but I thought I'd share. (At least this is what happens in MY car.)
Car: 2017 Ford Mustang Ecoboost Premium
Phone: Axon 7 (Gray)
Yesterday, I noticed that the music was rather bland, muffled, and rather quiet. Switched to CD and Radio and almost lost hearing. Unplugged the phone from the car and tried a reset. Same results. 
Went into the phone settings and turned Dolby Atmos off. (I had it on earlier showing off the demo for some people at work.) Plugged back in and music was back to being VERY clear and loud. Just to make sure, I turned Atmos back on and tried again. Music returned to being quiet and muffled. 
So, if you are using your Axon 7 with Android Auto and the music seems, "off", try turning Dolby Atmos off.

title: Received your Axon 7? Share your thoughts!

thread.text:

Posted via the Android Central App
I'm interested too! I ordered the Quartz so I'll be anxious to see what people think since they'll get the Gold one before I get mine.

Ditto bro...
Posted via the Android Central App

Got mine this afternoon. Just finished setting it up, but I still have lots to do. The fingerprint scanner works quick and easy. No lag or stutter at all. It came with 39% charge on the battery so i charged it as I was setting it up. The supplied clear soft TPU case fits nice and I think I will use it. There were no updates to the OS. I had no issues at all with my 128GB Sandisk microSD card. Signal strength shows 2 bars, but so does my Galaxy S7 Active right next to it. It got a little warm while setting up, installing and updating several dozen apps (but so has every single phone I have set up). Right now it's cool as a cucumber. The supplied fast charger works fine. Haven't had it long enough to judge battery life, but if reviews are correct, I should make it a day with no problem as I'm not a gamer or heavy user.I've only taken a couple of photos in the room with room lighting. They were well exposed and sharp. I don't see any issues with this camera unless you're taking pictures in near total darkness. So far so good with not a single complaint.

thread.text: Can anyone tell me which is the max exposure time on its camera?

I'm loving the hardware. I didn't realize how awesome a fingerprint scanner would be on a phone until I was able to unlock LastPass with the touch of my finger!
